data.title: What Are Organizations Doing To Include Inclusivity And Diversity In Their Hiring Processes?
data.content:
LinkedIn's Global Recruiting Trends analyzed that diversity and inclusion (D&I) is a key trend that has impacted the way organizations hire workforce today, especially post the pandemic. While 78% of organizations promote diversity to improve culture, 62% of companies prioritize it to boost their financial performance.

The report adds that 'companies making meaningful efforts towards diversity, equity, and inclusion, as well as providing a sense of belonging, have invested in their people through supporting employee resource groups (ERGs) and having a strong backing from their leadership teams.'

Other studies show that almost 57% of recruiters think their talent acquisition strategies are designed to attract diverse candidates. But is it really so? What can organizations do to maintain D&I while hiring potential candidates?  

  • Awareness of unconscious bias — First and foremost, organizations and HR need to be aware that multiple unconscious and intentional biases do exist in the workplace. And that steps are required to mitigate the same. According to Associate Dean and Director of Office of Inclusion, Belonging, and Intergroup Dialogue at Stanford University, Mohammad Bilal, 'unconscious biases do not necessarily align with our conscious beliefs, which means unconscious biases are even more important to pay attention to.

 

  • Provide fair opportunity — Organizations must provide a fair opportunity to every candidate who may have the skill sets to take the organization to new heights. Increase diversity and inclusive hiring by managing candidate sourcing well. A great way to ensure that your talent pool is full of diverse candidates is to source your candidates from various places.

 

  • Develop D&I training programs for HR — This will help HR teams to understand how cultural differences can impact the way people work and interact. It could include working out of different time zones, altered communication styles, self-identity to their reactions and response in times of conflict.

 

  • Increase your diversity hiring in candidate screening — The criteria for hiring usually include demographic and geographical information. To have D&I goals in the organizations' road map, it is essential to use tools and intelligent systems to hide those biases and promote hiring based on merit and skills.

data.title: Nextgen Technology Trends HR Will Need To Adapt To
data.content:
Gone are the days when we inserted thick cards into machines for in-out time tracking. Then came fingerprint scanners that were used in all walks of life, and now it is our retina's that are scanned. Thus, it won't be wrong to say that technology has taken over all domains to make life easier. HR is no different. In fact, PeopleStrong says, 'Indian companies can save at least $600m annually by 2021 using HR Technology.'

 

So, what are the nextgen technology trends that organizations will need to adapt to, and HR will have to pay the way for?

 

  1. The bubble called Cloud — With everything moving on to a virtual platform, it is imperative for HR to keep most data on the cloud for real-time use, primarily since the millennials and the GenZ will dominate the next generation. They are dominated by the need to work from anyplace-anywhere-anytime, and it will be essential to move everything to the cloud for instant on-demand use. 
     
  2. AI augmentation — Increasing technology use is not enough. It is important to use it smartly to achieve target-oriented business impact. With augmented AI, analytics will be sharper and decision making stronger. With AI-enabled data on skillsets vs job descriptions, HR will be able to hire the right mix of candidates who could benefit the organization in the long run. With the use of AI in analyzing employees' career goals, HR could address their learning and development needs preparing them for a bright future. 
     
  3. BYOD - With the invasion of multiple digital devices, data and device security are becoming an essential aspect of IT and HR teams. The future will see HR asking employees to bring their own devices as they would be unwilling to sync their professional and personal lives on company-owned devices. This will also reduce dependency on company-owned devices leading to business benefits.
     
  4. Tech for gig & Hybrid — Organizations are moving towards gig economies and hybrid working where it will be crucial for organizations to provide round-the-clock technology solutions for accessibility if not availability.
     
  5. IoT in HR: With remote working and the rise of the gig economy, HR may feel the need to adopt wearables to track time, monitor health, fitness etc., with cloud-based services in a secure ecosystem.

data.title: Forced To Say Goodbye? Try These
data.content:
Industry reports across the spectrum have been talking about increasing attrition in various industries and sectors. And it is a growing concern for HR since workplaces and work itself are seeing a significant change over the last year. 

 

However, there are times when the organization has to take a tough decision and ask an employee to leave. Reasons may vary; it could be that the company needs to reform and the existing employee doesn't fit in the scheme of things, or they may have been unproductive. Whatever it is, one thing is common in all these situations - heartbreak, hopelessness & low confidence.

 

So, what is it that HR can try to do before asking an employee to leave?

 

- Find the root of the problem. Try to infer the reasons for the employee's deteriorating performance and work towards it. It could be that there is a strain in the employee-manager relationship that is decreasing the formers' productivity. In this case, a communication channel needs to be established to understand and forge the differences.

 

- Speak to the employee to understand their aspiration and match them to organizational goals. It could be possible that the employee may be good in another field that they may never have paid heed to. 

 

- In the case mentioned above, HR could speak to leaders and the employees' immediate manager to try and find an alternative, if possible. Thus the employee could be moved to another project or team.

 

- Put a 30-to-60 days plan in place where the employee can be coached and corrected.

 

- Access the employee's records to check where the employees' passion lies. Thereafter, HR can initiate a mentorship program to upskill the employee.

 

- Reset Work Expectations And Create A Plan Together. It could be that the employee needs a level-setting. In that case, it is essential for HR to reset the expectations and put together a plan for their success.

data.title: The Millennial & Genz Workforce: What Makes Them Different?
data.content:
Millennials & GenZ’s are probably the most maligned group in the professional circle. By 2025, the generation of Millennials will comprise 75% of the global workforce. And together with Generation Z, they will dominate the workplace in the not too distant future. 

For HR, this means that it’s essential to know some of the characteristics of these generations – think of their work styles, values, and beliefs – of workers to provide them with an optimal work environment.

 

So, what are the top 5 ways to ensure their engagement within the organization?

  • Talk more about passion and corporate branding than about the money
    - 92% of Millennials believe that business should be about more than just profits
    - 30% of Born Digital employees would leave a role if they felt the organization lacked purpose
     
  • Collaborative Work Environments
    Both Millennials & GenZ’s believe teamwork is an essential aspect of building a high-performance organization and look to encourage and promote this working style.
     
  • Flexible Working
    For them, the new working world is all about choice. 82% of born-digital want employers who give them autonomy. Although a five-day week is still popular, they believe that they should be allowed to work a four-day week if they choose. They also want to decide when, where, how, and how long they would like to work.
     
  • Leverage Technology 
    In a world of distributed work, tech tools and messaging platforms are critical for maintaining a sense of company culture and enabling effective teamwork.
    Only 26% of business leaders are optimistic about using instant messaging apps for work,  compared to 82% of Born Digital workers and 83% of Millennial employees.
     
  • Effective Dialogue & Feedback
    This group doesn’t believe in annual feedback or dialogue during appraisals. They believe that they, the organization and their peers will only grow if there is an effective communication channel the whole year-round. Building employee confidence is a great way to help get and keep them motivated and enthusiastic. Also, what gets recognized gets repeated, which means creating a culture of recognition and performance goes a long way in motivating them.


The Millennials and GenZ prioritize empathy, human values and employee well-being more than profitability. Thus, HR needs to thread their path effectively to hire and retain them.

data.content:
Hi, I'm Anannya, and I lead content at EDGE. We are in conversation with Arjun Pratap, CEO, EDGE. We will be discussing the possible future of hiring and how our latest product, EDGE Recruit, is poised to act as a catalyst for change, both for recruiters and organizations alike. Welcome, Arjun.

 

Anannya Debnath: I was in conversation with Dinesh yesterday, where he mentioned that this year, hirings are going to go up, given there was a lot of attrition, lot of job losses last year. And this is in line with the Future of Work 2021 global survey, which says 82% of employers are looking to hire this year. So what is your opinion on this? How do you see the industry now?

 

Arjun Pratap: So I mean, hiring has been a perennial focus because everyone's looking at hiring primarily because everyone has attrition when people want to look at change. But hiring is one facet of the problem. And I'm going to focus on that facet, and why hiring continues to be a problem which is a lot to do with the way we hire, which fundamentally, if you look at the statistics, also, when you talk about the future of work and the state of talent acquisition, its various reports are being generated primarily because of the world-changing its way of delivering value or creating value through steady-state businesses, or verticals, as we know it, they're reforming, refactoring to deliver this value to their consumers and to their customers. And hence, the need for people within the business to help them restructure is of paramount importance. This is why I think there are two facets of it, the loss of your job or the job loss side of is one piece of the writing on the wall that we've already read. The other is reinvesting in hiring people, which has become the next mantra because you're trying to figure out now, based on growth, that you visualize how you could get the right people in to deliver the outcomes that you want. So hiring will continue going through the roof. I mean, an economy like the US, which is, I think, investing $6 trillion, and its restructuring and rewiring will see a boom. And that's a signal to the rest of the world because they are the number one in terms of GDP, followed by China, and they are looking at how they can bounce back and deliver this value post-COVID, which are seeing real signs through various facets of the ecosystem. 

 

So, I think the answer is that talent acquisition will continue seeing a change because people will figure out how to solve the same problem in different ways. After all, other facets of that one problem will start becoming efficient; some facets will continue to evolve or stay inefficient. And then therein lies the ability to create that opportunity and start tapping into it. 

 

Technology is only going to provide you with a means to an end. And when I say it in a very simplified way, it's automation, data science, analysis, input, information retrieval, etc. These various things will come in and play a part in helping people identify the right talent. So I think that's where talent acquisition is and where I think there's a huge, massive opportunity over the next decade.

 

Anannya Debnath: As we discussed before this, Mercer's recent report states that organizations across the spectrum take a very long time to hire. Only 20% hire within a month; the rest take a cycle of almost three months to fulfil a position. Now, if you could elucidate how EDGE Recruit can solve this concern? And how are organizations poised to benefit from it?

 

Arjun Pratap: So, my theory of life is not based on my concept or my perception; it's about being in this domain, understanding hiring the way it understands it from people who are a lot more accomplished in hiring as you mentioned, Dinesh from our company was, you know, in JPMorgan Chase. He understands hiring competencies, talent acquisition, retention very well. And like that, I've met a fair few people within our business, our customer base, to help understand what we bring to the table that changes the game. It's not about searching and matching in AI as we know it; this is the science that comes to mind. It's also about helping people through a process. And that process has to get streamlined. The process has to get efficient. The process has to get very nimble. So, simplification of this process is of paramount importance. And what happens is when users like you and I are also recruiters or working with recruiters based on our needs? We also have to understand that as a user, as a recruiter, I'm used to an Ola, Swiggy, Uber or Netflix, which is very nimble and simplified in its ability to navigate. And that's the same, that's using a B2B application. 

 

So, our effort in EDGE Recruit, as with most EDGE products, is to simplify these talent decisions that recruiters are trying to make on behalf of a hiring manager or a candidate who wants to join a company, tap into an opportunity. Making that efficient making that simplification possible through user experience, across different filters that we gave across different stages of the process, is really where it counts. AI will also compound the benefit by learning across the steps of these events and starting to calibrate, re-adjust itself so that the product begins to deliver better results through the heuristics that it picks up in some of the signals that it already has within the system. So, EDGE Recruit is a great product because it's focused on simplification. It's about the user, and the user is the recruiter, in my view, who's going to continue to deliver this value of bringing somebody on board – it is very critical to performing within your organization. That process has to be simple. It's also about delivering that automated, clear, simple set of steps to help the recruiter suddenly move from I'm shortlisting the candidate, I'm screen candidate, I'm going to help schedule an interview, I'm going to help, schedule an assessment, then, you know, start the verification processes or multiple things, and then you're doing it for 50 people. You sort of lose your marbles at the point.

 

If this process can be simplified and automated in many ways, the information is available to the recruiter. What happens is that the recruiter starts diving back and giving the candidate a better experience in terms of the onboarding, the journey about understanding the position to lead the outcomes. And that conversation is got a lot more value. So, I think as recruiters focusing on making sure that the dialogue between the recruiter and the candidate is very streamlined and very valuable. So, we have done the other pieces that we could automate and make easy for the recruiter to access.

 

 

Anannya Debnath: Arjun, there's a lot of AI being used in the hiring industry today or if we could say that organizations and recruiters are moving towards it steadily. People are going digital; organizations are increasing their technology adoption. If I could ask you, what changes will we see shortly with the combination of various technologies and AI being into play? How will it benefit the organization, the recruiter, the employee - everybody in that circle?

 

Arjun Pratap: So, the changes are going to be simplification. It is also about the different niche or point solutions working together. So, the sense of partnership and collaboration is going to be a reality. And partnership and collaboration will then start giving you what we call platform benefits. So, the platform will then start housing different pieces of the puzzle or various parts of the process - from meeting a candidate through their resume or their profile and starting to engage with them as they go through the process. That I think is going to start becoming platformized. What is going to develop future or forward-looking from that is the ecosystem. In an ecosystem, you will have multiple players within the niches that will start defining their set value props, which companies then can pick off depending on what they need for what part of the process and what they deem is fit for them. 

 

It's like the Ambassador and the Fiat? Both are cars. Which one do you like because of the shape, the size etc., is your choice? Likewise, you will want a specific assessment partner, a specific interviewing software, a specific background verification partner, and a specific set of companies you want to hire from a particular interview set to interview in a panel. How would you modulate all of that? If that is simplified, and if that becomes platformized, then what you're doing is navigating the person through that, rendering the recruiter drive more value into being like a concierge service for the candidate to move across into

onboarding. And I remember the Ex-CHRO of HCL, Prithvi Shergill, citing that this should be like a concierge service. I think it does make a lot of sense. His vision was to somebody, literally from being identified to being onboarded, have it happened within five hours. Can you actually run that assessment interview process, screening, background verification, and offers rolled out within five hours? It seems euphoric and sort of ideal state, but it also appears believable and doable. 

 

And I think at some point, people have to believe in simplification and compression. I know some of the customers we deal with. Incidentally, HCL is a customer of ours. They have really visionary people sitting there and moving things to define these processes faster and better. We have people in Wipro who are constantly looking at streamlining and making it the most efficient recruitment process. Just giving a few names, but we have close to 500,000 IT services, employees transacted across a platform, and millions going through the recruitment process. So, it's a benefit that we drive. Platformization is one key area of significance. Some people expect our companies to be platformed, as a virtue of them having a SaaS product, but platformization is also about allowing multiple products within a company to be housed in multiple products outside of the company; it also is housed in, and that's really about true platformization. And then the ecosystem where you're starting to look at how you can better be the general community through the ecosystem. And I think those are the stages that we will see talent acquisition move through.

 

And in benefiting the candidate, the case, since everything will move, the position will be filled up filled faster. Candidates will be chosen based on merit, without any bias, in the process because some of the focus areas have always been, how do you build in diversity and inclusion? How do you build in sort of an equitable process? How do you be meritocratic? And for that, do you have to take some of the conditioning or the unconscious bias that we have out of our systems and technology today plays a huge part in making it a level playing. And for that, you have to build your AI, right. You have to build your product right. And I think all technology companies are focusing on delivering that value through the product thesis of solving that problem in a genuine sense. And I think companies are benefiting from that. This is why many companies have a change in the ratios that they have a difference in the kind of productivity and impact that these ratios give them, which is an important facet. You are building a company to be productive and delivering value. But the other side of it is, you're also missing out on the fact that the candidate comes in with a lot of promise and how you guide them through the process and how you guide them through the journey of being with you is so important. It's about getting that fitment organized and reorganizing or reshuffling that fitment based on the aspirations of the person and the organization's aspirations, personal success to the organization's success, critical to correct, and my belief that I can see in the products that cater to it. It's not something that's in the making; it's here to deliver value. And I think we're at the forefront of providing value through our product, making kudos to our team who has worked really hard on, you know, setting that targets for globally competitive products and creating this value for the candidate for the recruiter for the company. So we are meeting those sorts of very linear sets of intervention points where it's necessary to solve these problems; otherwise, they are very disconnected. They continue to provide a lot of inefficiency in the system.

 

Anannya Debnath: Right. So, what's more, in the sense that, what is the roadmap ahead, for EDGE, for EDGE Recruit and the industry?

 

Arjun Pratap: Yeah, so for the industry, it's about obviously fueling the many companies and the many people who need to meet with companies that are a constant focus. There will be a consumer-focused set of applications; demand focused set of business-to-business applications will continue to be built. It's going to see many that change primarily because the jobs are evolving in the nature of the construct. What kind of skills you require, what kind of competencies you need, what kind of depth you require is still in the air, and it's being fleshed out to start becoming table stakes and understood. That's where companies like us continue to play a part in the definition. Once the definition is real, then the identification happens. And then, the planning is also a part of the process. So we believe that the definition of identification and planning is very vital to the circle of employability and gainful employment.

 

It's essential to be in that mix, where you're looking at all the signals across these different industries that require people in various capacities because of the way they see themselves today delivering similar outcomes or the same outcomes. It's just morphed because automation is rife, efficiency has come in, technology has provided changes to the sense of direction, in one sense, or the sense of speed, to achieve production that's already been oriented. So I think for us as a company, we believe that we will go out there and really be the career guide to every individual on the planet. And for that, we are building products that will start first on the simplification level, where talent decisions are being made, where we can help companies across that process, help candidates across our process and support employees across the process. So we have a few products that we've built on a talent decision platform that focuses on the employee, focus on the resource managers, recruiters, workforce planning and forecasting pieces. And it's all focused on the people pillar. And I think that's the area that we believe that as a forward-looking movement, the opportunity to build internal talent, places and opportunity marketplaces and deep platforms exists. And we're going to tap into that because we think there's the value that we can create based on our line of sight in the company.

 

Anannya Debnath: Great. So, thank you, again, for these great insights. It will really help our viewers/ readers get a sense of what we are doing and plan to do in the future. 

Have a good day!

data.title: What Goes On Behind An Adept Talent Acquisition System?
data.content:
Talent acquisition without a talent acquisition system is like getting into deep waters without a lifejacket. It entails a gamut of exercises from shortlisting applicants to screening them, assessing to final onboarding. While recruiters strife for the best, leaving no stone unturned to find the best possible candidates, their inability to assimilate the latter's updated information, just-in-time insights, time to join, salary expectations etc., at one place and then matching them with open positions makes the task extremely tedious. Resultantly, a talent acquisition manager takes, on average, 60 days to fill a position.

 

So, what is the solution? What can recruiters do to fill this gap?

 

Well, they need an adept talent acquisition system that can take over their mundane tasks, giving them scope to perform core functionalities. It should ideally be an intelligent system that integrates multiple applications and platforms that make the task of hiring simplified and effortless. 

 

This is where EDGE Recruit comes in. Our latest innovation isn't merely a system of workflow but a system of intelligence. The brain behind EDGE Recruit is our Smart AI EDGE GraphTM - an astute knowledge graph, which has analyzed over 10 million job descriptions and 35 million candidate profiles. 

 

From collaborative hiring to storing an employee's holistic profile, EDGE Recruit - our AI-enabled product, possesses the capability to parse through a gamut of profiles within few seconds. It then provides you with instant and accurate matches for a job description based on criteria like skillsets, diversity, or location while tackling unintentional and unconscious bias. Recruiters can also search for candidates based on time and cost sensitivities enabling improved conversion rates. 

 

EDGE Recruit also possesses the ability to source from multiple job boards. Basically, organizations have their repository of different resumes that they have collected over the course of the period, either through career sites, employer profiles, or recruiters themselves, which were never maintained. However, when there is a job in hand, all the talent acquisition manager is trying to do is find the candidates who can fulfil this position. There are multiple sources through which they scout for resumes, the first being their internal talent pool. At most times, it is either incomplete or possesses redundant information. Thus, they go to multiple job boards for the same. EDGE Recruit solves the talent managers woes by auto sourcing candidates from job boards directly so that they never run out of CVs, giving them an entire market to explore through. The product can be used for reverse matching as well, where a single resume can be matched to different job positions within an organization. 

 

Our technology aims to enrich the recruiter's end-to-end experience - from sourcing to interview scheduling, qualitative feedback collection from assessment partners to final onboarding. Simply put, it is an employee-centric solution helping organizations focus on their long-term business goals by putting the talent at the nucleus. And this is precisely what an adept talent acquisition system is supposed to do. 

 

It is interesting to note that the Global Digital Talent Acquisition Market is expected to grow from $22,791.04 Million in 2020 to $33,498.78 Million by the end of 2025. Though it poses stiff competition, products that focus on agility of workflow and workforce are sure to end as winners. 

 

EDGE Recruit ensures recruiters are able to accomplish more in less time, adding value to the organization. It also enables talent managers to get ahead of the competition by onboarding the right mix of people & make better hiring decisions. This is how we use tech for good.

 

Book a demo now; allow us to show you how Recruit can be your catalyst for change.

data.title: EDGE Recruit - The Catalyst For Change
data.content:
I am Anannya, and I lead content at EDGE. We are in conversation with Neha Chauhan, our Product Manager for EDGE Recruit & Mobility. She talks about EDGE Recruit - our latest offering, how the team stumbled upon the idea for the exciting product & gives a sneak-peek at its features.

 

 

Anannya Debnath: Welcome Neha. For the uninitiated, she is our go-to person for EDGE Recruit. So, without wasting any more time, we'll get on to understanding the various aspects of the product. Also, we would be really interested to know how the team & business leaders harped upon the idea of EDGE Recruit?

 

Neha Chauhan: Sure, so I'll take you back to how he started his journey. We started by matching internal employees to the job openings within an organization. And that is a journey, we continued for a little while. And it was eventually search-and-match that we were doing; we had the jobs in hand, we knew what the job is asking for, we had employees on the other hand, and we could match those employees to the candidates. We soon realized that this concept of search and match does not remain constricted to just internal employees; the same could be applied to the external market. And that's when we tried to filter it off to external markets by matching the same job instead of employees, the external candidates. And that is the idea that eventually developed for EDGE Recruit. 

 

While we were good at search-and-match, this is the journey that continued for us for a little while. A couple of years back, we tried to rehash what we were doing so far until now. So, while we were really good at what we were doing until now, i.e. search-and-match, we realized that this is just one small part of the entire problem. There are a lot of other issues that are still lying unsolved in the whole recruitment function or the recruitment cycle. If you look at it, recruiters, on average, get about 400 applications, which can go to 10,000 or so. For a human to sit and go through all those resumes is an impossible task. And that's why you keep hearing those keywords 'make your resume catchy'. Frankly, people glance at it; you have three seconds to catch their attention. You are not the only applicant. There are 1000 more people like you. If I put myself in the recruiter's shoe, that is the best they can do. Either they can go about going through those 1000 resumes in a linear fashion one-by-one, or they would randomly pick up the resumes or something. If something is interesting, it is prioritized. Now, in that entire day of work, you would tend to lose some excellent candidate that was matching your requirement and was not at a high cost.

 

There is no way for you to figure out in one glance who is the best among those 1000. How do I even prioritize? And that's what we provide. We provide a stack ranked list of candidates by matching those 1000s of candidates to one job in just seconds. The recruiter has to review each profile no longer to understand what all skills they have, is good or bad, to match the job at hand. All that task is done and presented to them readily, to see who out of those 1000 are the best match to the job. But this, too, is solving just one part of the problem. 

 

When you look at the entire recruitment cycle, you have to source the candidates from multiple job boards and screen them. After that, you need to check everybody's availability to get the interview scheduled. There are numerous systems involved where a recruiter will have to go and update their status, keeping so many people in the loop, including the candidates. This entire process in itself has a lot of problems. And that's where almost two years back, we started our user discovery session to give a fresh look at what we were doing so far and how we can improve. We spoke to CHROs of Fortune 10 companies, hundreds of recruiters in IT/ITes services, our existing clients, and the other ones. And those user interviews are what helped us in realizing the gamut of problems that lie in this space and how this entire function had transformed over the past few years when we started our product journey.

 

So, those user interviews are something that helped us in identifying the problem statements. I had my own hypothesis, my own theories laid out. I wanted to ensure that my understanding of the problem statement or my idea is what I wanted to validate with the actual users, which are the recruiters. This is the cycle that went on for quite a reasonable amount of time and for a very long time, dwelling in the problem space to figure out all the problems that lie in this entire recruitment cycle and the problems we're solving for. In the first version, we cannot solve everything, but I have tried to solve the product key problems that I figured out from all of these interviews.

 

 

Anannya Debnath: And so, you know, as you said, this is version 1 of the product that we're launching now. So, what were those features that you thought of when incepting EDGE Recruit? And how has it changed today? What new features have been added, and what features can we expect in days to come?

 

Neha Chauhan: One of the key value propositions of EDGE Recruit is the ability to source from multiple job board's. So each of these organizations has their repository of different resumes that they have collected over the course of the period, either to career sites, employer profiles, or recruiters themselves going and getting some resumes. So there is a repository that they have, but you can think of it as more or less just a database, which was never maintained. You would find my resume lying in there, which was years and years old. So it's no more applicable. If you look at that resume, it will no more apply to the job you must be looking for. So when you have a job in hand, all you're trying to, as a recruiter, do is try to find the candidates who can fulfil this position. Now there are multiple sources through which you can find out those candidates. You would first start with your own talent pool - your own repository of data, which has its challenges presently. It's not maintained, it's ancient, you wouldn't have updated information, even the candidates' contact information is unavailable maybe, and so on. The next step is to figure out where to find the candidates, and then you go about who to contact. Now, even in the market, there are multiple job boards. And for a recruiter to go about doing that, they will have to go log in individually to each of the job boards, figure out who all the matching candidates for the requirement and have all of that information consolidated somewhere in an excel or something right. So that is an overburden on the recruiter. So you don't have to go to multiple job boards trying to figure out the candidates. From our application itself, you can auto source candidates from job boards directly so that you will eventually never run out of CVs. You can keep on increasing and improving your talent pool through this auto sourcing. Of course, you will never run out of talent pool; you have the entire market available for you to explore through this auto sourcing.

One of the other key features that I would want to discuss is how the recruiter's KPIs and the parameters they are judged upon. So one of the KPIs is employee referral because they are pushed towards fulfilling a maximum number of positions coming in through employee referral. Now, that cycle is also somewhere broken in a sense; when an employee would refer their friend or someone against a particular job. And that is just a one-time opportunity. It could be hit or miss for that person. If the referral matches the job, you're through. If not, your resume goes in vain. Nobody else will look at your resume after that to figure out that this person, although referred for this one job, has better opportunities that he/she may be able to fulfil in the organization. So, why can't I take the person's resume and see if this person matches some other job? And it might turn out that we have a better opportunity for this person than something that they applied for.  

 

So we provide this reverse matching as well, where one part of the flow is you have a job in hand, and you're just trying to find the matching candidates for that job. The other way around is also possible; you have a resume in hand, and it looks good. It might not be a good fit for the job you have presently, because as a recruiter, your visibility is restricted to few jobs that match your own. But if I have this resume on the system, and there's an ability for me to figure out that this person fits ten other jobs, why can't I proceed with this resume for those other jobs. It helps recruiters meeting their own KPIs and fulfilling positions for the employer. And even actual data says that there is a higher possibility of closure, of any candidate eventually even joining you if it's coming through an employee referral. Otherwise, in this entire scheme of things, a candidate might end up not joining you after making you wait for 60 or 90 days of the notice period, which to an extent is solved if it's through an employer because the confidence is already in place for your organization when it's coming through an employer. And that's precisely why even organizations that try to push for employee referrals above other categories are going in the market and trying to find resumes. 

There are a few more exciting features that we have introduced, and I'll take a minute to talk about those particular ones. So one thing being ours is an AI system. And we genuinely believe that any candidate, if they are to be screened, should be filtered based on their skill sets' quality and experience. Nothing else matters. With this tool, we are trying to take care of the unintentional or unconscious bias that may creep in while looking at a particular candidate's profile. We are trying to take. It could be anything - gender, liking towards a specific organization etc. A candidate coming from a great organization might create an unconscious bias towards favouring a particular candidate. However, there might be another candidate equally or even better than this specific profile. So in this tool itself, we provide means for you to tackle the unconscious as that may come in screening and ensure that a candidate's screening process is limited or is happening only through their qualifications and experiences, nothing else. Diversity and inclusion programs are people promised visions who want to deliver upon right now.

 

 

Anannya Debnath: It is gaining ground these days everybody's talking about. It's a company on vision these days to maintain that. Yeah, it's a very, very important part.

 

Neha Chauhan: Absolutely. I mean, precisely the need of the hour as well. It is necessary. The women representation, in particular, and has to increase, and it's great that it's two of us talking over here for this interview. So through EDGE Recruit, we all want to help recruiters and help the organization meet their diversity and inclusion goals. It could be gender, people with special needs, or veteran status etc. So whatever an organization's diversity goals, our product is configurable to meet their specific requirements.

 

 

Anannya Debnath: Is there anything else you would want to add to this. Are there any features that were probably thought about but not implemented in this version? 

 

Neha Chauhan: I can give you a brief, not in terms of features, but what we have in our roadmap and how we are thinking to solve the recruitment cycle in full. We aim to help recruiters with resume screening and interest check emailers, candidate management or interview scheduling. We are thinking from wide angles, across different stages of the recruitment cycle, and how to solve them.

 

 

Anannya Debnath: So, it's like behold, a lot is coming in. Till now, we were talking about EDGE Recruit as a product, its features and how it's going to help recruiters. Now, we'll speak of it in terms of business impacts. What are the business impacts it will bring for organizations? 

 

Neha Chauhan: To answer this, I will categorize three organizational goals we are trying to target - time, cost, and quality. The time it takes for you to hire or close a position, the cost you are hiring for a particular position, and the quality of hire you're bringing into your organization. Time and cost are understandable, and everyone talks about those, but I will specifically talk about the quality of hire. How are we intending towards improving the quality of hire? So, we're adding AI algorithms to assist the recruiter in assessing a candidate by providing just-in-time insights that they may have missed and are critical for the particular position in hand. So, we experimented a lot and figured out that performance capability can be assessed through social grouping. When I say social grouping we are currently looking at GitHub and StackOverflow. Your entire scope of evaluating a particular candidate so far has remained restricted to just their resume. It is their impression in a snapshot, nothing else beyond that. And if you look at it, there are many different areas where people showcase their capabilities.

GitHub and Stack Overflow are the top two sites that I would go to for developers. GitHub came to India in 2018-19, I think. And by 2020, they had more than 1.8 million developers who joined GitHub. As for their estimations, by 2023, like nearly two years later, they expect there will be 10 million developers who would have joined GitHub. And India, for them, is one of the fastest-growing markets. There may be many projects and activities that the developers would do or have had a repository of at GitHub and Stack Overflow. So, within the product, we intend to provide a view of all that a person does, even beyond their resume. We fetch all that information, activities, etc., and give a recruiter a picture of what they're doing beyond the usual. 

This, in turn, helps in validating what the resume is. Nothing stops a candidate to declare what they want in their resume. But when you can see proof of the same in the activities that a particular person has been doing, it helps you validate and be confident that this person poses what they claim to be. Suppose all of those are taken care of in the earlier stages - during a screening. In that case, your probability of taking many people over to the interview stages and then falling on the numbers drastically, would also decrease. The reason being you will be proceeding only with the candidates who you believe are really true to their word. And have the capability to clear the interviews, right. The funnel that exists right now is very heavy until the interview scheduling and then suddenly drops. With this in place, the funnel will be tight from the beginning stages itself until the hiring.

 

 

Anannya Debnath: Thank you Neha. We got a lot of insights about the product. I think whatever we've spoken here is really going to help us push EDGE Recruit to the other level. So, thank you so much for your time. It was a pleasure speaking to you. Take care.

 

Neha Chauhan:  It was such a pleasure talking to you. Thank you so much. Take care.

data.title: The Issues In Hiring Right!
data.content:
If the latest figures from the Future of Work 2021 Global Outlook report are believed, then the hiring industry, post the pandemic, is in for stable growth. According to the survey, more than 82% of employers are planning to hire in 2021. Of these, 37% plan to re-hire to backfill jobs and 35% plan to hire new positions. In this context, it is crucial for talent acquisition managers to steadily gear up for future recruitments.

 

However, is it as easy as it sounds? 

 

At the onset, hiring may look like a piece of cake, but the reality is far from this. On average, a recruiter receives 300 CVs for a single position. And they are looking at multiple posts at one time, which means they are scouting 100s of CVs daily from numerous job portals, making notes tirelessly to match them with the job requirements in hand, shortlisting candidates, contacting them, scheduling interviews, working on feedback, and onboarding them: all at the same time.

 

The problem

1. Analyzing scores of applicants from various job portals, recruitment agencies etc.

2.         Going through each one of them tirelessly, jotting down the skill sets and matching them with the job requirements. 

3.        Connecting with shortlisted candidates, screening them, checking the availability of all parties, scheduling interviews

4.        Post-interview feedback from managers & department heads 

5.        Generating the offer letter & rolling them out to the candidates

6.        Maintain a log containing all these details and regularly follow up on status and intent. Thereafter, assisting the candidate until onboarded

 

Dinesh Menon, Head of Operations, EDGE, says, "a recruiter spends most of his time sourcing and sharing. And because of this today, if you really look at it, many recruiters are not doing a recruiters job because they are just busy getting a CV, running it through the TA team and pushing it across. They aren't really doing the interview process, which they're hired for. So what is the recruiter's job, what is the value a recruiter brings? It is to really interview a person, understand the candidate's profile, understand what he or she knows, what the job requires, see a match in terms of the fitment in terms of behaviour, or skill sets, in terms of culture fit, and so on, so forth."

 

The solution

Lack of astute and intelligent mechanism act as a detriment to logical hiring. Most functions are manually processed, taking a considerable time out of the talent managers' board, leaving them no time to focus on other vital pursuits. The need of the hour is a product that provides a holistic approach giving an instant 360-degree hawk eye view of a candidate’s skill sets, across platforms, at one place, that can be matched to those required for a position. 

 

EDGE Recruit, our latest innovation, is integrated with multiple applications and platforms that make the task of hiring simplified and effortless. The brain behind EDGE Recruit is our Smart AI EDGE GraphTM - an astute knowledge graph, which has analyzed over 10 million job descriptions and 35 million candidate profiles. 

 

From collaborative hiring to storing an employee's profile, our product EDGE Recruit can parse through a gamut of profiles within few seconds to provide instant and accurate matches for a job description based on criteria like skillsets, diversity or location, tackling unintentional and unconscious bias. EDGE Recruit also allows seamless integration with multiple social profiles to provide insights about the desired candidate. In addition, our technology aims to enrich the recruiter's end-to-end experience - from sourcing to interview scheduling, qualitative feedback collection from assessment partners to final onboarding.

 

Resultantly, it allows talent managers to screen resumes faster, enhancing shortlist to interview time by almost 60%. Additionally, they can now save about 30% of their total recruitment time by identifying the right people for the right job by reducing knowledge gaps.

 

"Once the right person is identified with the help of EDGE Recruit, it's about going into the next stages of the hiring. Like I said earlier, you have assessments and so on, so forth, and you can move in so that it really brings in value in terms of sourcing, helping you source the right person in a much, much effective way. And you know, that not only reduces turnaround time but your costs and enhances the quality of the CVs that come. This streamlines operations and ensures a recruiter's exit doesn't hamper the brand deeply," adds Menon.

 

EDGE ensures you put your talent managers at the nucleus, making them feel valued and future proof in your organization. It helps them accomplish more in less time, adding value to the organization. This is how we use tech for good.

 

Book a demo today. Let us show you how EDGE Recruit can be your catalyst for change.

data.title: Automation vs Augmentation — A paradox of sorts
data.content:
Automation? 

 

Augmentation? 

 

Or both? 

 

What is the difference between the two? Can they work together in conduce? This is the perennial perplexity faced by organizations, especially the talent acquisition teams that aim to make hiring simpler but accurate.

Though talent acquisition professionals worldwide have been reaping the benefits of artificial intelligence (AI) benefits or the last few years, they rarely understand the difference between the two. There are numerous misconceptions regarding their application and benefits that form a constant barrier to its implementation and usage.

 

According to a report from Entelo, more than 70 per cent of the HR workforce believes that automated sourcing would improve their productivity levels. Furthermore, the research conducted by Oracle and Future Workplace revealed that 50 per cent of HR heads already utilize some form of AI at work, a massive increase from 2018, where it stood at 32 per cent.

 

A buoyant recruitment model requires successfully implementing both technologies at heterogeneous touchpoints for informed decision making – from screening applications to sending emails, scheduling meetings to compare different candidates.

 

While on the one hand, automation takes over mundane tasks like screening resumes, scheduling emails and calls, as well as other manual chores, augmentation takes on complex roles of intelligent information gathering and analytics, on the other. Thus, low priority but tedious regular jobs are automated, giving precedence to professionals to focus on mid and high-level tasks. 

 

The hiring begins with automated processes and provides more intelligent solutions with augmented capabilities; it supports talent managers with unbiased, non-judgmental and astute hiring solutions. An ideal hiring process with the right mix of automated and augmentative AI should be something like this - automotive AI scans through thousands of resumes, and augmentative AI assesses each profile for its novel experiences and distinctive traits that make it unique; to provide talent professionals with the candidates who best fit the job profile. After that, automated AI takes over the regular tasks of scheduling a call/ meeting with the candidate, sending them updated meeting requests giving the recruiter scope to face-to-face interviews and assessing the candidates‘ skills compared to their resumes. An intelligent talent management solution also accords the recruiter to recomb the large pool of unhired candidates who may have gone through the interview process smoothly but were never hired. This pool provides top-notch candidates who may not have the requisite experience but can immensely contribute to organizational growth.

 

Augmentative AI can also help talent managers compare the skillsets of recruits to other successful hires in the past, creating a powerhouse of data and hidden gems that can be mined as and when required, instead of relying only on new resumes every time a new position opens up. This can be clearly understood in times of the pandemic – with the pressure to increase performance and downsize the workforce, organizations all across are facing a tough challenge. They could hire the best talent across industry lines and categories but ensure they could deliver. Thus, the barriers of location, geography, timelines have disappeared and what has remained is diversity and inclusion. Today, a person sitting across the globe could be recruited to fulfil a particular position handling complex jobs, which could otherwise only have been performed by aspirants from a specific sector or city. However, this can only be successful if organizations provide the right tools that enhance collaborative work. According to KPMG, almost 70 per cent of business leaders are working towards building on their use of collaboration and communication tools, and 67 per cent of them are more likely to invest in technology.

 

Capgemini believes new technologies will challenge the HR organization by making parts of the traditional operating model obsolete. According to their report, over 35 per cent of the conventional HR workforce will face massive changes over the next 10 years to augmentation. 

 

Hence, automation and augmentative intelligence must work in tight synergy to achieve fruitful results. We need to understand that AI is not an all-encompassing solution; preferably, its benefits permeate various levels of the acquisition process, sometimes in nooks and corners we may not even tend to realize. 

 

The better understanding of automation vs augmentation, the more productive and cost-effective the talent management team is, and the better opportunities it has to implement industry-leading AI systems and processes.

data.title: NVIDIA On Emerging Workplaces & The Boundary-less Workforce
data.content:
Suranjan: Tell us a bit of yourself, share your experiences

 

Amit: Like, I mentioned earlier, working from home for over a year has given us all an opportunity to rediscover and reimagine ourselves. So, with over 25 years in the HR industry, pretty much most of my professional career has been with two companies, Intel & NVIDIA. I joined the organization when it was a fledgling company with a lot of ambition to establish a global footprint. I've been with them for 15 years now, managing the India region, which comprises India and Southeast Asia, & is the largest engineering presence for NVIDIA outside of the US, close to around 3000 direct employees & 1500 contractors. I manage the entire HR group for the region.

Additionally, I also play the role of a site leader who is the cultural ambassadors and the fishery keepers for the organization. So, I manage it for Bangalore, which is the largest site that we have in India. And clearly, the last year or so has been transformational for us. We reimagined & reinvented.

 

Suranjan: That's amazing. Are you introducing some theatrical production stuff as part of your cultural change? 

 

Amit: We actually are. We are typically a very, very serious tech kind of a company, very work-focused. And we believe that people derive joy from work. But in the last year, we've actually put together a set of programs that helps employee's kind of showcase their talents. And, incredibly, there are so many hidden gems and lost skills in the company that we were not even aware of. It's been a successful initiative since the human side of the enterprise has come to the forefront. It's impressive to see how leaders have become a lot more transparent and a lot more palpable as human beings, as against just people who were kind of setting direction and energizing people to accomplish business outcomes. But it's incredible to see the personal side of the leaders across the company as well. 

 

Suranjan: How have the employees in the region you govern coped with the pandemic from a personal, professional and workplace level? 

 

Amit: I think it happened in two phases. I think, when it started off, there was an element of crisis that had kind of hit the organization and the employees. And people were trying to figure out how they make sure that they continue to deliver to the expectations. And I think there was a little bit of heroism that was kind of coming in, right, which is that people thought it's a crisis, they need to go above and beyond. And they were actually kind of getting to a stage where they were in a crash and burn mode. Right. And I think the way I look at it that roughly around a quarter, into it people realize that this is not kind of going to go away. And it is not the time for going above and beyond. But it's about making the adjustments needed to kind of acclimatize yourself to the new way of working. Some people were burning out in the initial stages. They weren't infrastructure constraints they were dealing with - they were kind of trying to grapple with managing the personal crisis, as well as their desire to kind of continue to find meaning in what they do from a professional perspective. But I think they have now gotten used to the new normal. Obviously, as a company, we have kind of created an enabling environment as well.

We told them not to worry about the deliverables work and take care of themselves or your family. That is a priority. And we kind of extended to the level where we said we don't want even our contingent workers and partners to get impacted. So we decided where we want to pay everybody at the level it is, and they don't need to be worried from a financial perspective. 

The employees of today have a potent social conscience; they're not only looking at in terms of what you're doing to them. But what you're doing to the larger ecosystem as well. Secondly, we pulled in our increment cycle really fast, assuring our employees that we are there for them. The third thing was that very quickly, we enabled them from an infrastructure perspective. They were ID packs that were kind of built-in in record time and were shipped to employees' homes, which meant that they had all the infrastructure needed to get productive. We quickly introduced a $400 subsidy for people to buy furniture from home to create the right economic environment office environment.

So I think these helped to nurture a lot of confidence. Lastly, we made our top leadership a lot more visible. We had virtual visits from our CEO & the entire leadership team together communicating 'we are in this together. These things helped us create what I would call an environment of comfort, which was very well received and well appreciated.

 

Suranjan: Now, yeah, that is amazing to hear. Because as they say, it's difficult times when humanity comes out. So, I think the social contract that all of us have with each other shows up in these kinds of times. And I think it's it did, in all the cases that you talked about. From the perspective of NVIDIA being a tech company, did you face the situations of needing to rescale, retrain & understand what works, what doesn't work from a talent perspective? How has that changed, if at all, for you?

 

Amit: Actually, it's not changed significantly for us, other than the fact that now we have a much larger universe to kind of work in. And, it is actually a boundaryless world as far as talent is concerned. And that's a massive plus for us. Most technology companies, including ours, are highly innovative and research-focused but have not had the building blocks to allow employees to work from home. I think the concept was not alien to us.

What has changed dramatically is the way work is kind of getting done now. Culture is a big challenge that most of us have. How do you ensure that your culture is experienced by the employees currently operating in a remote kind of environment, especially when we hire more people than we've ever done? In the last year, even if I look from an Indian perspective, our hiring has gone up by 30% from what we've done in the past. From a business perspective, we are getting into new areas, expanding ourselves. A skill set, for instance, that we built over the last year is in the networking space because data centres are a big focus area for us. Over the previous 12 months, we've actually made more investments in newer areas than we've ever done before as well. We looked at it as an opportunity where we could reimagine, re-explore and actually reinvent a lot of the things that we were doing. 

Our hiring has gone virtual. For so many years now, we were trying to, you know, kind of, get technology adoption when it came to recruiting people. We had middling success, I would say. In the last 12 months, I think we have made giant strides in everything that happened; our platforms have gone virtual, the adoption of technology and tools and predictive assessment tools have just kind of gone through the roof. In these 12 months, what we've learned is that that's the easiest part? You no longer have the resistance, you no longer have the criticism, you no longer have a fear of trying something new. And, you know, for instance, I mean, our entire college hiring was done virtually through tools like hacker ranks and some of the other technologies that we're using. It actually broke down some of our deep-rooted construction behaviour that organizations have that the best talent. And we were able to expand our reach efficiently, and instead of having five IDs and 10 NIDs, we could reach out to 120 colleges at the same time, and roughly half of the talent that we hired actually didn't come in from those colleges. And it was a massive paradigm shift for our managers, as well, who said that you know, let's not kind of just focus on the conventional ways of doing things, and let's kind of get a little more unconventional, and there is a goodness to it as well. So, I think many of our paradigms have taken a shift in the last 10 months or so. And change management has never been easier. Digital adoption, self-service models - most companies' kind of struggle with it. And we are not behind because we have a very, very intimate manager centric, employee-centric approach.

 

Suranjan: No, I get that. So now there is obviously a side to it, where the getting feedback in-person feedback, the engagement in, in physical terms used to be kind of the norm earlier? How do you see that play out? You might have gone through reviews and feedback cycle? 

 

Amit: Employee surveys are dead. Pile surveys are the way to kind of go forward. We are now doing very, very quick, short pulse surveys every two months. And we are doing it on a thematic basis. Right. In terms of trying to understand what is on top of people's minds. For instance, our first survey was about how you kind of looking at work from home, and what is it that is, what is your confidence level in terms of coming back to work? And what would make you more comfortable? And there were some interesting perspectives that kind of came in there; a lot of people said that I don't mind kind of coming to work, but I'm really, really kind of concerned about the well-being of my family. And my second most significant concern is whether my co-workers are going to adhere to the new working norms. So, it's not about me, I'm confident I'll be able to do whatever you're asking me to do, or whatever I know the government was telling me, but I'm not too sure that my co-workers will be doing that. It was also very, very clear to us that people are saying that we want to kind of, we want to kind of come back in phases. And perhaps the future is that I would 60% of our employees said that I don't see myself coming into work more than two to three days a week for a few hours, and make it more focused and make it more thoughtful as against just coming to work because I am expected to kind of come to work.

Surprisingly, you realize the millennials and the younger employees are more interested in coming back to work because they were missing the social connection. They want to come back to work because work-office & social interaction is a big part of life. I don't think people are going to be wanting to work from anywhere. I think they will want to work from the location and may not be necessarily from the office. So, there's a lot more flexibility that's going to kind of come in there. 

Our second poll survey was about collaboration and saying as to whether collaboration is working. There was some intense feedback that came in there saying that keep the business running kind of stuff, things that I'm already doing well. 

Employees are missing interacting with co-workers. They make one-on-one conversations, but that informal, inorganic way of just kind of shooting the breeze is kind of missing. On our end, however, ideation is becoming a challenge. Whenever it comes to new ideas, new projects, we are struggling with that. We're still trying to figure out what's the best way to create that. There are obviously virtual tools to assist some of that brainstorming, whiteboarding, all of that. However, people want what I call shooting the piece, right? Kind of seeing the other person's reaction, the body language makes a big part of how work is done. They are also missing their informal coaching and mentoring, you know, that thing that hey, if I'm stuck with something, something I just walk over to somebody, I get it resolved, and I move on with my life. Today, I have to kind of make a deliberate effort to kind of set up a call, do a meeting, the type of stuff, but it is interesting, right? The way I look at it, you know, three significant shifts that I have experienced are the shift from employee experience that companies are focused on to kind of managing what I call the employee life experience now.

 

Amit: Three significant shifts that I have experienced are the change from employee experience to employee life experience, understanding the challenges around parenting, life challenges, and finding ways to help them address them. Mental wellness, a psychological hub in India, our utilization of that has just kind of gone through the muscle gone through the roof. 

 

Suranjan: Absolutely.

 

Amit: Initially in India, you know, people are very, very sceptical to say, hey, if I go to an employee assistance program, there is something wrong with me. Now, that actually kind of look into it as a very, very meaningful tool to kind of help them cope with their life scenarios. The definition of work-life balance has changed dramatically. It's no longer about work-life balance is about work-life integration. Traditionally, it was about giving flexibility to people to kind of work from home. Now people are looking at flexibility in terms of time.

We had to kind of go and reconfigure all our meeting ecosystem and eliminate many of our meetings. So, I think that the whole concept of work-life is undergoing a shift. I think the other thing that has been significant learning for us, and I think at a macro level, will have implications in the future as well. That I think countries, regions, states, cities are no longer going to be focused on attracting companies to come to their core to them. And the emphasis is going to be in terms of attracting talent to come to them.

Also, I think managers are learning new skills as well. Empathy & mindfulness is something that is a unique trait that they would they are being forced to kind of develop. So suddenly, the appetite for behavioural programs, and a lot of managers, you know, have this kind of a little bit of trepidation when it comes to soft skills sort of training has gone up tremendously. And people wanted short, they wanted personalized, and they wanted contextual. So, storytelling will be the most critical skill that the leaders are going to want to need. And empathy is probably the most prominent skill that the managers would have to learn in the future, and I think we got no easy answers for this; I think all of us are kind of learning as we go along. 

Technology adoption, I think, again, is a given at this point in time, and we're probably going to see a lot more a lot quicker adoption of tools and technologies than we've ever done in the past.

Recruiting is a low hanging fruit that's already kind of accelerated. Learning and development will follow as well because it's going to become hyper-personalized, almost like the retail shopping experience kind of stuff. And we are going to be required to sort of change the way we kind of deliver training and the kind of training that we do because people are not interested in looking at general principles. They are looking at more contextual stuff. 

Service providers would also have to look at how they will make their offerings customized - a lot more flexible and a lot more relevant to clients as against having a big platform that can tweak a little bit here and there. So, these are the big things that we are kind of seeing now.

 

Suranjan: You referred to the advantages of the boundaryless workforce that you can access now. Within that, obviously, there is this whole gig workforce concept that is playing out as well. In this boundary-less environment, it gives you a more significant opportunity to tap into talent across the VDI environment and your contingent workforce environment unlocked by location. So how is that helping you? And also, from a talent perspective, helping your talent tap into roles and jobs in different parts of the world for them? Right? Is that something which you've seen pick up?

 

Amit: It's a mixed bag. I am a little worried because it also means that there will be a higher propensity for the US and Europe to start hiring from India. And, as the talent truly kind of, I mean, it's a reality that we would have to kind of contend with. And in some ways, it's a challenge because then we need to sort of up-level our game to make sure that the work that we do is equally meaningful and equally attractive. After all, increasingly, we see that many companies, the US, have now started to hire people from India for jobs.

And, and in some cases, they're paying them US salaries as well. So that's, yeah, that's something that we would have to kind of contend with. I think the other thing that companies must be cautious about is that there are still legal and compliance issues that companies have to deal with as you get people to work from home. It's not that easy for me to kind of get somebody to work from a restaurant. I mean, it looks great. But if he's using my hardware, it kicks in, for instance, some GST implications for us? How will personal taxation kind of work? I think it's more pronounced in the Western world, but increasingly, in India, how do I make sure that I am compliant with the local laws? And in India, we do have a federal structure where each state has its own employment laws. But having said that, I think if I look at the talent behaviour, they have become a lot more open. I hired more people in Delhi last year than I have done in the previous 10 years. Because, you know, it was challenging for us to move people from Delhi. And then suddenly people are kind of attracted by the quality of work by the quality of organization that they're going to be going to work in, under location does not become a significant factor as well. 

However, I think the gig stuff will probably take a little more time to pick up. I think it's still pretty nascent at this point in time. From an Indian perspective, there is a little bit of trepidation. How do I kind of make sure that the person is working for us in the limited time they are working for us, they're giving their 100% kind of totally committed because it's not about just the technical skills? The biggest challenge for companies is the expansion of the skills that you require from your workforce. The more significant trend is re-skilling employees, taking people from their specialized zones and converting them into full-stack. And I think that's the biggest challenge that most organizations would have. And therefore, putting in programs, bringing in technology that understands what the skill map in the company is going to become a significant, big imperative. And I think a lot of us are kind of struggling with it now. And I know your company has some solutions there.

I think it's a sweet spot at this point in time. It's not external looking. It's not about where the talent lies outside. It is where the skill lies within the company. And how do you kind of utilize that? And with the barriers of location, time zones being removed, I think it's like a huge opportunity, a significant imperative for organizations in terms of how to identify what your skill landscape is and how to do you kind of leverage the underutilized talent within the organization. And I think creating those skill inventories, understanding where they're skill-wise, and how best you can sort of leverage it, and create opportunities for them to do to bring their best to work, I think is going to be big.

 

Suranjan: Great. So, Amit, I know we've run over a little bit. I hope that was okay with you. I think this has been awesome. Thank you so much.

 

Watch the full video here: https://bit.ly/2RVywAx
