data.title: Coping with Stress Of Pandemic - A Session By NASSCOM Product Connect - Part 2
data.content:
Part 2

Dr Apoorva Joshi:  A lot of us have hesitation when it comes to accessing mental health. So, despite the awareness campaigns, despite everybody coming up and sharing on social media, especially and Bollywood celebrities speaking out in favour of it, we still see a lot of people going into denial and seeing that they probably don't need it or hesitating, because of some other reasons. So, Arjun and Dr Jyothi, I would like to hear some of the challenges you see daily that individuals hesitate to ask for help?

 

Arjun Pratap:  Statistically, I think there have been a lot more people approaching mental health now. It was 2% of workforce which went up to about 8% of people. But having said that, I think the idea is that people reach out not just to professionals but to each other too. So that's also a critical point of intervention. I believe the professional help avenue is also just by statistics of reference points of the number of therapists doing sessions; I think it must have gone up dramatically. I think that's the aspect that we see and will continue to persist, where people are looking out for a medium of connection and intervention and change. So yeah, and I urge people to reach out. It's just normal. It is essential, and it is necessary to do it now versus doing it two days later. Yeah,

 

Dr Jyothirmayi MD: Thanks to the pandemic, mental health professionals are now categorized as medical doctors. So, they will also be able to prescribe medications for the disorders and do therapy. Sometimes we are asked to hide our identity as a psychiatrist and talk to them as a general physician. With celebrities talking about mental health issues, at least the stigma is now coming down. With more online consultations today, we're doing therapy sessions and consultations in remote towns and villages. Also, we can now consult in conference with kids, who are abroad, and their parents. 

Identification is the most important thing because people suffer from sleep disturbances, panic attacks etc. The very sensitive indicator that I can tell every individual is to understand if you're sleeping well. If you have an excellent sleep and your appetite is good, more or less, your mental health issues are sorted. In major mental health issues, sleep is a very sensitive indicator. Sleep deprivation can start a vicious circle of low mood irritation. These days it's challenging to diagnose mental health issues because of excessive mobile phone usage, overwork, and stress. Overflow of news is also an important factor in losing sleep these days. It can be hazardous if people are 24 into seven with the movement; they keep on checking information/news repeatedly. 

Let us be productive, focus on our work, immediate family members. So, smaller steps can make a lot of change. Let us at least try to help people, hold hands and speak a few encouraging words. I think that would create a lot of impacts.


Dr Apoorva Joshi: Yes, very well pointed. So, can we take up some questions from the audience? 

The first question is for the both of you. So, a dear founder friend had a difficult situation where three of his employees left their jobs and went on long breaks to overcome the tragic loss in their families. And all these three employees were great workers. So, the founder is confused, whether he should reach out to them and hire them back? Or should he leave them? What's your take? 

 

Arjun Pratap: So, if they've gone on sabbatical and they've gone out and returned to find themselves and get past that point, definitely reaching out to them to say you're there. And whether they're in the organization or not is essential. I think that's the right thing to do. Whether they can come back because you require them, you can say it the way it is and leave that thought with them. But I think you should also do as a founder because you owe it to yourself and your business and potentially your investors to get on with it. So, you need to figure out how you can get people who can replace their skills and competence are the rules within your organization to get on with it. If they're going to come back, give them the option based on your need, and get on with it to figure out whether you can move with different people coming in and, you know, supplementing in terms of their roles. Also, they have to understand it's not open-ended; you need to get on with it because you owe this to yourself, and you need to or obviously to the company that you're building the dream you have. 

 

Dr Jyothirmayi MD: I think first reach out to them. Sometimes people in desperate situations leave their jobs, but they would be in search of another. If they were happy or content with the first job, they would be satisfied, even if the founder would have approached them. But if you know, they are still stating that they can't join or get back and are still very busy with their thing. It is a challenging situation, but he has to keep going by employing maybe new people and going forward, and it should not be seen as a failure.

 

Arjun Pratap: I just wanted to add one thing. One of the things that I learned through the journey, through many mistakes and failures, is that self-flagellation, as a founder, you got to own an account for what you have with you, right? It's a context of time. The fact that you reached out and asked this question is a great thing; hopefully, you get some takeaways from this and act upon it. So, there's nothing wrong with you reaching out and saying, listen, are you alright? And nothing wrong with you telling them, if you want to come back within the next month, it would be great for us, and probably getting your head cleared, and then coming back would be great for us. And, you know, I want to be able to take that opportunity to work with you again. If you find an excellent person to take their place in that month you need to communicate that to them through that journey. So you know what, two weeks have happened. And I've met a great person, and I'm sorted right now, and I'm going on; I want to let you know, thank you for being there and sort of thinking of coming back still. But you know, I've got this sorted out, now constantly have to make those tough choices. And one will be, you know, wrong to somebody else, but right to marry other people. And you got to think of that in this, make that decision and live with it. Right. I think you need to deal with the accountability and responsibility of making that decision. 


Dr Apoorva Joshi: Another question for Dr Jyothi, in particular, is - can you suggest some practical tips for all the stress and the anxiety that is stored within one's body?

 

Dr Jyothirmayi MD: Broadly, we can classify these coping skills as physical coping skills, emotional coping skills, and social coping skills. So physical coping skills is the utmost that we'll have first to sit and understand whether we are taking care of our body correctly or not. I/f yes, then only the body will be able to cope with the other kinds of stress. And the second is the social coping skills like connecting to other people, trying to be in touch with friends, neighbours, or family members. The third thing is emotional coping skills. Emotional coping skills are different for different individuals. Some people are doing 15 or 20 minutes of physical exercise like yoga or something that rejuvenates them. It makes them feel good because it is like all the muscles in the body are involved. For some deep breathing exercise, like a five minute of breathing in, breathing out, just focusing on the breathing, trying to lessen/ increase the depth of the breath. Concentrating on it for five minutes works a lot in reducing anxiety. For some individuals, it is their hobbies like cooking, arranging, or cleaning up the home. Even these are some activities that reduce our stress and anxiety about household chores. 

It is spiritual music for some people. They get a lot of anxiety relief by praying, believing in some higher self, chanting, etc. Whatever works for anyone, I think people can get any coping skill that they can take up. 

 

Dr Apoorva Joshi: Thank you for sharing that. Our next question is for you, Arjun. What are some of the tips you would like to share with entrepreneurs, how they can best manage their resources, which are primarily constrained at these times, like money management or employee retention? 

 

Arjun Pratap: one of the things that I realized in the journey, and what happened to a lot of startups who were on the B2C side, is that they had to deal with the changes; and we had engagements that our investors conducted for the portfolio companies talking about how they did sessions, usually every day, with the workforce and the employees to keep them connected. And because they're trying times, there was salary restructuring and reorganization rescheduling in various forms and manners. But I think in that time, what I learned was to be connected to your people is very important because you know, whoever you are, is because the people you have, and the sort of the dream will get fulfilled for them with you. So, it would be best to be very clear about that being the connection point for them. Why would they want to go away at this point is very basic, simple things, financial security, job security, the realization of self-worth in their jobs. These are essential things that you need to re-emphasize through this journey. And you might not be able to find ways to provide more financial security. In fact, it might be less financial security, but communication is the key. Lay out a plan and go early on the day with a message because people must understand that you're trying your best to organize this whole thing for them and yourself. Founders have to make that and work on ways to ensure that it is not all about money. People will want to shift to another job or want to move to another company or want to get more salary within your company. You will probably realize what your situation is if you're authentic and straightforward about the situation.

Don't try and profit from the situation. I'm not saying that that's the motivation for everybody at this point. But make sure that authenticity comes in that sincerity comes in that integrity is something that employees see because they joined you b because you're passionate about doing something within this company and taking your risk with you. Do not forget that. So that's my two cents. I believe strongly in people who built a company around solving the problems of translating the economics around employability and ensuring that people get the right jobs. And being at the goal of empowering and enabling companies to, you know, look at that talent, and then the transparency will give them all the power they need to perform. 

 

Dr Apoorva Joshi: Dr Jyoti, would you like to add on to it? 

 

Dr Jyothirmayi MD: No, I think that was very well answered. So being genuine to everyone around the company spirit should never be let down. The founder has to make it very clear to the employees the critical purpose of the company.

 

Arjun Pratap: I'll give you another insight. I tend to begin my day by getting up at 6:00-6:15 am and then starting to check my email around 7 o'clock. And I'm a big believer in making sure that I get a balance of exercise because that's my de-stress. And I figured out different ways to do it in this lockdown. But as I begin the day, there was an I've been, you know, sort of, you know, trying to push the bar and work through the day. And I've been talking for really long hours, which also affects your eating and all the other things that are not balanced. What I was looking at through the day; this is what other founders and looking at it, they were meeting scheduled like one after another to the degree of it spilling over, and you have to manage your time really. It's something that you can't do anything about your need to be there. And then I had this meeting invite sent to me for 9 pm. Tonight, from 9 pm to 9:45 pm. Tonight, and I was here and saying, why can't this be done on Monday? Right? The fact that my colleague wanted to do that meeting at that time motivated me to say, Okay, I'm going to do that. Because why is someone wanting to do that meeting is because they're so interested about doing that meeting, they want to want to meet on this really relevant topic. Right? It's important. So you need to also figure out through this and condition yourself for it so that you're there for the long haul because it will be a trying time. You need to take these avenues that Dr Jyothi talked about and not be taboo about this word mental. Ensure that you are all right to perform and since this direction setting for all the people out there. It's imperative to realize that while everybody has all these different things happening in their lives, you maintain a sense of balance. And guys, we're all human. So, if you falter a new fall, speak yourselves up but realize it's okay. It's not the end of the world. 

Yeah, because this motivation is also contagious. Even if one employee in the companys' been a little bit more motivated, I think he can motivate the rest of them. Yeah, I love the fact that my colleagues are encouraged, and they're, you know, they, you know, it just makes me continue and deliberate and immense, I wake up because they wake up, to be honest. 

 

Dr Apoorva Joshi: That's a beautiful way to put that. So, in fact, we've come to the end of our time for today. And I would like to thank both of you for sharing your valuable insights. And it has been such an exciting discussion. And I hope the founders and the employees and everyone, and all the viewers were able to, you know, take back when key points and learned, you know, how to better manage their stress during this pandemic. So, thanks to both of you. Before we end, would you have any final concluding remark from both of you?

 

Dr Jyothirmayi MD: For me, I just want to tell all of you that this too shall pass. It's not going to stay forever. We will survive this, and it will pass, and there are good times ahead. 

 

Arjun Pratap: I couldn't have said that better. And I think we share eternal optimism, which is excellent. Dr Jyothi, I believe, as you said, this too shall pass. And there are better times ahead. It's just a realization that we have to go through that we are responsible for this destruction somehow. It's not the government or not the policymakers alone; I think we need to account for this chaos that has been created. And let's not deflect and displace our emotion. It's really up to us to start figuring it out. Let's start owning that part and getting this in order. And it shall pass, and we will see better times. And that's, I think, the writing on the wall. So guys, hang in there, make sure that you know you don't beat yourselves because you feel like you're alone. Reach out to each other. It's essential to reach out to a friend, colleague, family, have a discussion. It's okay to be angry, it's okay to fight and also feel sad at times. But you know, you're going to move on. And it's not that Dr Jyoti and I are not in pain, or we haven't had our set of setbacks exist, that it's vital to have a positive attitude. And yeah, think of things with a rainbow head and a silver lining. Yeah. So thank you, guys. Thank you for having us.

 

Dr Apoorva Joshi: Thank you, both of you, for taking out precious time today. And thank you to all the viewers who've taken their time and ask the questions. And please feel free to reach out to us in case you have any other queries. So with that, we'll end today's session. Thank you all once again.

data.title: Coping with Stress Of Pandemic - A Session By NASSCOM Product Connect
data.content:
Part 1

Dr Apoorva Joshi: Good evening, everyone. I'm Dr Apoorva Joshi, and I welcome you all to the special session on coping with the stress of the pandemic. And today, I'm pleased to be joined by Dr Jyothirmayi MD & Arjun Pratap. Jyothirmayi is a psychiatrist, and she's an export counsellor. And Arjun Pratap is the founder of a very celebrated startup, EDGE, and he manages a team of young professionals. So welcome both of you. And thank you for finding precious time to join us today.

So, India is currently facing probably the worst pandemic crisis in the world. And as we all know, every citizen has been deeply impacted. As days go by, we are experiencing more and more fatigue. So, coming straight to the point, Arjun, I would like to learn from you as to how the pandemic has impacted the industry and the employees? And what is your experience been like?

 

Arjun Pratap: So, my experience has been around, typically, my startup and my team and my colleagues and peers. And it's quite heartfelt, primarily, because the kind of empathy we required to make sure things are sorted must be with the velocity, with a deepness of understanding because we really started caring for each other in a deeper sense and in a more effective manner. So, when I look at my company, and we did a dipstick on the number of people who had COVID, who are sort of struggling to get tests done, some to get oximeters, some to get CT scans or different medication. It is important to connect the dots for them. So, you have to have channels open. And that's just the context of our company. And what I see is also the empathy movement, for instance, from our investors who come back and say, you know, we have a couple of companies in our portfolio, we are not aware of who also will help on oxygen, or will also help on getting your bed. So why don't you reach out this way? It's very heartening to see them pitching and delivers the message of connecting us to really help and empathizing with our situation. So, I think it is, it is important to recognize what's happening in the industry - companies are stepping up and saying, listen, we will, you know, take care of your vaccines, testing requirements; work from home, don't come to the office, because we are on a lockdown as well. But I think these are interesting times where the people element of the companies are starting to become a lot more real.

 

Dr Apoorva Joshi: Absolutely, absolutely. Thank you for shedding light on that. And so, how was the year 2020? And what is the difference that you see in the previous year? And in this current year? What are some of the challenges that you are seeing?

 

Arjun Pratap: It's a good question because the year 2020-21, in terms of the lockdown phase, is around the same sort of time period. But what we faced in 2020 was this whole view of annihilation and everything falling down. We were all panicking because a lot of things were breaking, a lot of businesses around was crumbling, and there was a lot of job and financial insecurity that was of big concern. So we went through different measures, like terminating our lease, cutting back on hiring and thinking about revisiting the structure of pay scales. Otherwise, how would we manage cash flows? How would we live another day? I think the sense was really April, May, June last year was about how to live, right? This year, if I had to reflect upon it, as a country, a lot more clear about managing it, and then we sort of lost the plot for various reasons. And I think the loss of the plot and coming back to the same state is fatigue. I think we're a lot better placed to deal with it because we have seen it in the past, but what we're dealing with is at a different scale. And that, I think, is the element of challenge that we have, because near and dear ones, every household, every family is dealing with it.

 

Dr Apoorva Joshi: Right. Thank you for sharing that. And yes, so every person has been impacted by the severity, and a lot of people have lost the near and dear ones. So Dr Jyoti, what are some of the major challenges that you were seeing in your clinical experience or diseases that people are suffering through because of this current pandemic crisis? 

 

DR. Jyothirmayi MD: See, the world is currently facing a major crisis. But at the same time, when we see the opposite end of the spectrum, we see people who are trying to help in their own way. They are giving their 100% effort in facing the situation and are putting themselves at risk. However, we see rising anxiety in people. 1 out of 10 is coming up with the anxiety symptoms related to COVID or post COVID. This ratio changes to 1 by 5 when we consider the worldwide scenario. So, mental health concerns are increasing by two folds. We wouldn't be humans without our fears. So, whenever there is a fear causing stimuli, the brain simulation centre of our brain called 'amygdala' is stimulated, and our body gets ready for a fight or flight response. However, in the current scenario, the stimulation modes are constantly ringing alarm bells in the body because of the constant overflow of news or negative information. So, the body feels constantly under threat. And it is seen in some physical symptoms of anxiety or palpitations where the heart beats fast, breathlessness, dry mouth, sweating or coldness of hands or the urge to go to motion. Additionally, people are anticipating and catastrophizing COVID thinking that they or their family members might contract the disease, assuming worst-case scenarios. 

And then there are depressive symptoms people are experiencing like sleeplessness, low appetite, PTSD, nightmares etc. Thus, a lot of mental health issues have suddenly cropped up; star employees have suddenly become poor performers, So, it's necessary to address these issues, put everything aside, strive to hold hands and walk together.

 

Dr Apoorva Joshi: I'm glad you raised the point that you know, we are seeing both ends of the spectrum that we have one stratum of people who are going out of their way to help out as much as they can and doing their bit even in service of strangers. And on the other hand, we are seeing survivor's guilt. So, these are two very extreme spectrums. And it's a very unfortunate time that we're are going through this at the moment. So, Arjun, from you, I would like to learn that what were some of the mechanisms that earlier, the employees would be able to do and unburden themselves. But now, it doesn't seem to work for them. So, she pointed out that some of the higher-performing employees might show a drop-down in their performance levels. So what are some of those differences that you've seen?

 

Arjun Pratap:  In terms of performance and measures of outcomes, I think the idea is to just keep things going, make sure that you continue to interact with a certain level of normalcy, to ensure that other people also don't feel this overwhelming sense of abnormality. Where, where everything is going shit, you don't want that to happen as well, right? I think it's important to try and maintain that sense of control and direction for the people that you're economically taking care of; you need to understand their compulsions of working as well. And certainly not take advantage of it but be there from an empathetic standpoint and manage them through the process. So part of the thing that we did last time was actually engaging them through gamification because all of us were in this digital medium where we were connecting as a way of life, and then that way of life became very, very effective because we could conduct meetings faster, perform better, but what we do not realize that were relegated to so much screen time, which causes fatigue at the backend. So how do you manage that fatigue through mental days off? So I've read a recent article that one of our Product Marketing team and one of my colleagues also brought up from the HR side saying, we should be evaluating this and just, you know, between yesterday and today, we went through a whole thread of what all can we do yoga classes, meditation etc. 

Leaders within the organization who have the responsibility and accountability to lead their functions and teams have to step up to the plate. And they're also going through their own trial and tribulations. Just because they have a leadership role to play doesn't make them superhuman. So this balance is very important. And it can only come if it's a two-way street. We are finally starting to understand that culturally we are a very empathetic society based on our development status.

 

Dr Apoorva Joshi: Very, very well put, Arjun. So like, as I shared that digital served as a medium for people to get an outlet. That was one, and you know, how the company was able to provide counselling, psychological counselling for its employees in the previous year as well. So, Dr Jyoti in you, I would like to learn that what are your key recommendations that, you know, employees and firms and organizations can do in such an extreme crisis? Like, what is your particular recommendations?

 

Dr Jyothirmayi MD: Let's say till yesterday we had something called Maslow's hierarchy of needs. So, till yesterday everyone was aiming at the higher level of needs. What usually happens is when the basic needs are fulfilled, then only a human being is loved or can think about the higher needs. In the current scenario, the basic needs are unfulfilled, and thus productivity/ creativity/ innovation is low. So here, we need to give that person some space, some time for people who are affected. This is where the organization's role is important. 

I have seen many big firms organizing employee programs like one-on-one talk with the employees or paying full salaries to those who get affected, And that is giving a boost for them- improving productivity, relieving stress and anxiety. So, I think that is what is happening when the basic needs are fulfilled, then only we can think about the higher needs. 

Usually, human beings have what we call defence mechanisms. So the most common immature defence mechanism that we resort to is displacement. Some people go into denial mode, especially in this COVID; they try to, you know, put aside everything thinks everything is normal, there's nothing much serious, nothing is going to happen and all that. So, the number of preventive measures and all that they take will be less. So, let us not go into denial mode; let us accept that this is the situation and all of us at some of the other quality of time is going to face this. In the employee-company setup, if one particular individual is not able to perform the work properly, maybe others who haven't been affected by COVID can take up that extra work or try to help each other in some way. And the founders and the higher authorities can just sit up with the employees and, on a weekly, you know, call basis, try to encourage them to try to address their issues. I think communication is the key here because maybe we'll have the intent to help them, but it has to be also communicated properly so that they understand the key; these are the resources that are helpful resources available to us.

 

Dr Apoorva Joshi: Great, ma'am, thank you. So from both of you, I could gather that paying attention to the individual's changed behaviour, and listening, and empathy certainly helps, and then taking action, according to that. So thank you for sharing those key pointers on defence mechanisms that you've just listed. 

 

Part 2 to be uploaded soon.

data.title: How a resilient HCL built their remote workforce
data.content:
Arjun Pratap: Hey guys, I am Arjun, the CEO and founder of EDGE Networks, a talent management tech startup based in Bangalore, India. And it's a pleasure to be here talking to 'the' Vikas Baghel, who's one of the members of HCL Technologies, a top-three IT services company globally, has 150,000 people and gives us a complete insight into our experience of what the term supply chain is. And I think in the past, he has been one of the people I've known and, in his experience for the last 15 years, has been sort of managing through our talent supply chain, enterprise social networks, recruitment firsthand, and talent management itself. So, because of his wealth of knowledge, I've learned a lot through my journey as a startup entrepreneur through the eyes of Vikas. And I've seen him in multiple forums, contributing to making sure that you know, employees, the workforce candidates, the entire talent management company is looking to better itself at every curve. So thank you, Vikas, for being a part of this, and it's great to have you talking to us today.

Vikas Baghel: Thanks for being kind. And thanks for having me here.

Arjun: So, the topic of the conversation today will be, you know, the new talent equation, and I think what we are talking through is returning to the post-pandemic workplace. And I guess it's been beaten to death as to what's going to happen and how it's going to happen. All of us are waiting for the vaccine, but we still don't know what that means for many of us. And if we had to take it to the work 2.0 sort of new normal equation, what are your views on the sort of new work environment that we see today?

Vikas: I think most of us have said that last year has been about a lot of realization, right, personally, as well as for the organization's I think some of the notions which we had in our head, all of us had a desire to give up from home, but we have a lot of apprehensions and inhibitions about it. One of the things is pandemic days; it cleared some of those inhibitions of some of those pilots we were running at a microscopic scale, we had to suddenly do it by force at a massive scale. And we got those results right! and all of us now realize that some of these are going to be new realities, that work from home perhaps it's going to be new reality and will not be talked as add on you're doing for employees. It will become a new normal. So, in light of doors, many of our organizations are also trying to consider how we should get back to you know if not all, perhaps 25% or 30% employees should come back to the office if they wish to. And I think that is one thing that will come as a post-pandemic trend where a lot of it will be driven by employees' desires. The whole aspect of employee experience will not be bogged down around technology, its tools, or features. It will also be about how the entire structure and the treatment of employees are going to be mated; it'll be about employee experience and the whole self of employee right, physical, financial, and mental well-being. And I think that is one thing which has changed now, earlier when we used to talk about some of these things, we were only talking about a specific section of it when we spoke about the experience with automation, technology, and all of that. However, now when we talk about experience, we are also considering aspects of financial and mental factors and health. So, I think these are some of the things and which are still early trends. But I think if the last year has been about reflection and introspection, this year will be about action for sure.

And, you know, honestly, it will give you more credit than you're taking. I think one of the things that I've seen, also through the lens of HCL, is that the fast pace not only bucks the trends but sets the pace too. So, one of the things I want to take this segue, you have been part of the employee first sort of journey. And one of the first companies that did it, at least from an India-centered standpoint, where you put the employee first in the middle of everything. And this was like, what, 15 years ago.

So when you look at the journey and look at what that means to you, I think you reflected upon it through technology, the process, automation, or a new tool that you'd give an employee. However, today, it's not about the means or the process; it's more about the engagement, the experience you're developing for them, and what are you catering to ensure that productivity is being achieved for the company as the employee. Right! So I think it's in the centre of that. The trends you see through the lens that HCL has specifically but more importantly, from your lens, because I know you speak very widely on employee engagement. How do you see the employee experience and employee engagement model fitting into a hybrid virtual work model? You do know a lot of that.

Arjun: Yeah, I think so many companies have come forth and said that as soon and, you know, and I'm talking about the large corporations who have come forward and said that we are not going to get back to the pre COVID kind of walk engagement where 90% of 90 95% plus workforce are going to be in the office. Most of them have said that it will be a hybrid model because we realize that it works. There's enough data for us to show that productivity hasn't gone down. If anything, perhaps people have worked harder than ever before. And it's a personal experience as well; I'm sure it goes for you too. While we were juggling these many balls - managing the kids, parents, and household chores, we have been delivering the same productivity and, therefore, to say that getting somebody within the four walls and roof for eight hours to do work is a myth. Thus, the hybrid model will be the reality, unless you are in a kind of job or role where you're forced to be in office because of certain compliance norms or the nature of work. However, I don't think there's going to be an employer who will force people to come to the office from now on; it will be on the wheels of an employee if they want to attend office. If that's so, I think there's this other side where people say working from the office is also about connecting with the people you know; when you connect with people, perhaps you achieve more, sort things out, and brainstorm together to come up with a lot of bright and innovative ideas. While many may say the same can be done virtually, it is not the same when you are in a room sitting across from the person. There you can connect at a different level; you can see the emotions, you can see how the other person is behaving. Thus, I think some of those things will be there, and therefore, the hybrid model will be the reality, the virtual will live, and perhaps it will become 60/40. For some, it could be 70:30 - more or less, but I think the realization is there. It is going to be the new norm. As far as experience is concerned, I read this exciting report at the global trend 2020 report. And one of the fascinating data was there to say most of the seats that would consider employee experience to be a vital topic, perhaps 48 to 50% of them. But most of them do not know to say what the benefit of it is? Can the employee experience drive my business outcomes? They can't draw that line. And that's a dichotomy we live in while we understand that, okay, employee experience is essential. And we need to do something about it. But how do I draw that line to say that if I make this investment in employee experience, what will I get out of it, perhaps company output or overall productivity? And that's where people like you will come into the picture, a lot of data analytics, a lot of trend reading, that give some sort of tangible data to people and the industry to say that, yes, there will benefit out of it. And you can draw the line; I think all of us at a gut feeling level know there is a benefit. However, if somebody wants to create some model and framework around it, and you know, table it to perhaps CFOs organization to say, I need this investment. And I think that's where there is a gap today, and we need that we need somebody is helped to sort that out.

Vikas: Okay, so this is an excellent point for all those startups who are sitting out there and building an effective employee engagement and an employee experience product because, for a large enterprise, it's crucial to draw the line between the ROI and employee experience. So, I think I hear you on that, because, when we go to functions that manage time and supply chain, you're at the segue of really aligning buildability, productivity to allocation and movement, including connecting train to deploy ratios to allocation, which is the same way of drawing that line. And people haven't been able to see through that, and you have this great product that does great things for employees. Hence, it's good to have, but not something that I put in as a line item as part of the annual operating plan. So I hear you on that. And this is also for all those startups out there who are building some great products to draw the line to the ROI. I've experienced it, you know, I'm a great fan of interacting with people across the table, discussion room is like glue when you're talking to people and ideas are flowing. But we don't have that availability today. And I don't know about tomorrow.

We'll have to figure it out. But we're starting to connect virtually and just make sure that we're trying to work around that missing piece. In my opinion, productivity has stayed together. Even Josh Burson cited this recently that financial security and job security are driving people to work harder, especially in the US, where there have been significant job losses to COVID and what the pandemic has done. Keeping that in mind, productivity is improved for all of us at massive levels. What does the organization benefit from in terms of a cost standpoint is lowering of cost? Is that a mantra that you see as a trend?

Arjun: The operating cost has undoubtedly gone down like the travel costs, for example - there has been no travel whatsoever for the last six months. And for companies of size and scale of ours, it is a considerable cost, transportation, for example, cabs, etc., which we provide to our employee. So I think some of those are low-hanging fruits, which all the companies have plugged in more so for the companies like us, who used to work in that model, where we always balance our costs and always keep a very close watch on that. But overall, yeah, as I said, I think there is enough data like the one equal to JustPerson there are people who have done it for the APAC. And all of them have come back saying that productivity has gone up. If not, as people were, you know, doubting to say that it might go down and whatever, for whatever reason. The reason could be the fear psychosis, as you said, there could be people who see that things are not going around. The microeconomic trends are very, very, very devastating, and therefore, people perhaps are working harder than ever before for whatever reason. Still, I think it is also to do with that is one aspect. Another aspect is that most of the employees who were trusted to deliver for the company put their best effort to ensure that we stay afloat. And I think that is the emotion that drove some of those companies, and we have read enough of those stories where companies cut salaries and did well after a few quarters. After that, the wages were reinstated. And I think those are the stories that tell us that the employee and the employer who put up hands for each other, took care of each other and navigated this troublesome time. I think that's the only notion to say that the people who work with you create value for you, while people who interact with your customers/consumers are the people you empower in all aspects, financially, mentally, or physically. And they will take care of you. That's all you need to do as management, as an organization - and the rest of it, they will take care of. I read this fascinating article wherein the author said that the CEO has become a chief empathy officer. They all empathize with their employees so much, putting themselves into their shoes and enabling all those changing the policies, processes, workflows, assuring career management and development etc. And I think that resulted in a great for many industries. And people have come forward and collectively did great things for companies to navigate through these challenging times. And I think that's, that's a very significant change. Right? We have been talking about it, all the automation technology, and we were also talking about it to say that what will happen to human aspects if that happens? Right? And how will we balance between technology and human right, and that this is a great example, we have never seen the kind of digital disruptions we have seen in the last six months. At the same time, we have never seen the employee engagement levels of being hired in 65% 75 unheard numbers. Yeah, these kinds of numbers have never come for employee engagement and, you know, employee satisfaction. So that goes to show that you know, you can balance out both, you can have a rapid disruption of technology, automation, all of that. And you can, at the same time, you can be more human and empathetic. And as long as you can create the balance of two, you can keep moving forward. Absolutely.

Vikas: And I think what you guys have done as an industry is a digitization at scale. I believe it has been one of the innovators, early adopters, in taking technology to solve parts of the process. I think many companies are looking at the model that you have and are learning. We hear from Josh that 80% of companies are going to work like professional services, consulting companies, and slash services companies. This is because everything is partly based on automotive companies operating in a pod-based model, a bank is working in a pod-based model, and banks have resource management functions today. I think that part is completely shifted, and I'm very fortunate to work in an industry that will be the next force of truth. So I've learned in that journey, and I think with that lens, I can understand what that means for, say, an oil company to change or pharmaceutical company to change looks like, as you have seen this journey, and you've seen it rapidly growing. You have also been a part of the reason digitization at scale has been achieved within your business. How do you see your employee assistance programs, for instance, as they work from home? Are you providing them with any assistance from the outside to ensure that they don't go into depression or not have issues with family, which are very personal things that we all were worried about?

Arjun: Sudden for us, and we have always had that these programs. To be honest, we had this, you know, we had these counsellors who are employed. Once they can reach them at any given point in time to discuss some of those personal aspects - they can take legal help, medical health, psychological health, whatever help they need. We had these massive employee engagement programs, which used to do for the families right there. We used to host this talent show for employees and their families where children or their spouse could participate. People did institutionalize some of those programs. And we started doing these more regularly - virtually because they were going through difficult times. And mentally, it was little taxing for all of us. All the news, which we've been hearing and seeing, the numbers in all parts of the world; we needed to do something to tackle that fear psychosis that was building because of media, and news and all of that was being woven taken care of, and then the employees. So it was an overt communication in many ways, along with these engagement programs, to ensure employees and tell them to say that we are with you, and now and you'll be taken care of in any sort of eventualities. So I think, I think that has helped to a great extent. And we have been very, very proactive in our approach, we kicked our business continuity plan way back in January, I think, last week of January, we could preempt because at that point, last year, November, October, news started coming that something was happening in China and, and all of that. So I think by January, we had this realization that it could explode. So we put up a plan around it. And by the time the lockdown was announced, we were all prepared, we had all things sorted, we were ready to move on the workforce for the virtual model. Thus, we could navigate without many hiccups, not only in India but across the world.

We've been lucky, and, personally speaking, I have been driving these digital transformation projects for a while. And all of them have helped. So when we were in complete lockdown all those technologies in the workflows and the design, which we have built over the years, it just kicked in, you know, with a snap of a finger and all our recruitment got virtual - onboarding, the candidate sourcing everything went virtual. It seemed like we were doing some sort of prototype for this kind of eventuality. It all became a blessing in disguise for us. And even the adoption has gone up, suddenly, we don't need to push anything, right? All the users started adopting the technology because they had no choice; they were in that kind of environment. So overall, you know, it worked out. When all our designs and programs are always built with that kind of eventuality - horizontally, we never build anything for the short term. Whatever we have we had created, it fits well for the situation we were in as an organization. And overall, it turned out well for us.

Vikas: In my view, you can redefine through the use of scrap. And I think the redefinition has been very successful because of your ability to consume technology beforehand, looking at different scenarios. And, you know Tom should have taken a leaf out of your book and done something for America. Having said that, I hope other people who are listening to it will take a leaf out of your book. I think your immediate response to the situation had been that much better since you had already played out some of these scenarios and taking into consideration some of these technologies as a path forward. So even in your thinking, just accelerating it in terms of genuine digitization at scale was really about the numbers you're playing out and the actions you're taking today because of what you've done, allowing you to do much better things going forward. So keeping that in mind, I think because a lot of aspects in terms of thinking from a strategic standpoint with talent supply chain are literally because you're taking care of 155,000 people across the board, managing them through this entire plan. In terms of the security, their purpose, their direction, and their commendable growth is something even I can't imagine. But I'm looking at 100 people in Edge and thinking about what that went through - we were going through sleepless nights, wondering what that would mean. And, you know, multiply that with the number that you have. It's just unimaginable. So hats off to you guys. The other thing that I wanted to highlight and talk about as we close this session is the gig economy and its workforce. We've heard this across that Gen Z and the millennial forming sort of the talent marketplace as we speak, and work product becoming more shorter, more short of space to how it would fit into an outcome. And there would be multiple pieces that sort of fit into the puzzle. What is that gig workforce represent to you, and how would you leverage the power of that going forward?

Arjun: We employ close to this - to put the numbers 8 to 10% of our workforce will be in that mode. And as you said, going forward, perhaps that number will only grow up. Because we're not working on some of these programs, where it's taking, you know, a woman who wants to come back to work and therefore, that in the real sense, it's got to be a gig where if somebody wants to work for two hours, or three hours a day, they should have that kind of facility. And I think that's a trend in the market as well, right? If we look at, you know your hobbies a few years back, your hobby today, and if that can become your profession as well. Some people write blogs and get paid for it, some give guitar lessons and get paid for it. And I may be out here for my hobby, but today I can earn money there, Youtube is a job, right? I create a video out of my hobby, and I'm gaining because of that. So somebody is a YouTuber on Saturday, and he's an employee of a company on Monday. So I think that will be a new reality because of all the trends, platforms, and technologies that are emerging. And therefore, you will always have more and more people who would be interested in doing multiple things - I may not like to do eight hours every day, five days a week, the same thing, I would like to do some three days, I want to do something else two days, I want to do something else. And if that is the scenario, the companies have to give that kind of flexibility to their employees, right. Otherwise, you will lose out on particular adequate talent segments, which you don't want, right?

Earlier, we used to only talk about build and buy right, either you hire somebody, or you retrain/rescale somebody internally using talent acquisition and management tool, This whole piece where you go ahead and take some of these people for a stipulated timeline to deliver your project and get done with it, is new. And then those people move on to the next assignment, and it will be a new reality. The whole aspects of those critical projects, which are short term, very time-intensive, high skilled resources, are required, which you may not need for your larger context. Sports teams where you source different players from different parts of the world create a Manchester United for a season when an EPL and then all those people go back to their countries and play their play for their countries. But just for that tournament, they get assembled as a sports professional sports team. Something like that will happen within companies, right? You will have those exceptional individual subject matter experts get together for six, eight months on a project to deliver the same in. Then they will go back to their work either within the company or outside the company. So I think the gig is gonna be the new reality because of these recent trends which are emerging. And I think most of us are still contemplating, at least in India, we are still at the stage where companies consider how I should put a framework around it? Okay, today, we are just consuming it in one pattern in one manner. Now people have started thinking to say okay because I'm not doing it at scale, I'm missing out on something. And therefore, I need to put some structure, some policy or processes around it to tap into this market.

Arjun: Brilliant. So I think when in summary, I think just the analogy that you gave about Manchester United. And that's a great analogy of getting somebody to put a team together to go, and we'll win an EPL, and then sort of go back and play for your country. And I know, if I had to drop back to working in 60 odd countries, you continue to use that flavour of working. And now I'm sure, you know, for people who are going to watch this. It's about following and learning from what are the trends to manage this process going forward; there's going to be a lot of insight because if you provide through many of your interactions across social media that allow people to learn from, you know what that means for the future of work. 

Thank you for a great session - it has been a pleasure as always interacting with you and picking your brain. It's been also taking time out from your busy schedule. So thank you very much.

Vikas: Likewise, thanks. Thanks for having me. It's great talking to you.

Arjun: Great, great. Thank you so much. Thank you.

data.title: Don't let your star performers leave
data.content:
What makes a great team and a company prosper?

Is it the leader, the employee, the work, its business policies, or the ethics that the company follows? The answer lies within - it is the amalgamation of all of the aforementioned; he or she is the ‘Star Performer’ or the Stakhanovite as we may call them. They take initiative, deliver results, communicate well, are passionate about the work they do, and have utmost integrity. They are the jewels in the company’s crown and the last thing you’d want is for them to quit. 

While most companies emphasize on hiring the best of talents, the effort should be equal or at times more to retain them. The most common mistake that most organizations commit is over-burdening their employees with work and eventually lead them to burn out. This often leads to attrition among the star employees.

Studies and surveys have revealed that high performing employees quit an organization for 3 most common reasons-

1. Excessive work pressure or disproportionate work-life balance

2. Being offered a considerable hike in compensation and benefits

3. To explore career development or new experience options

With the hunt for talent growing more and more challenging, it has become imperative for organizations to retain high-performing employees, not only to ensure steady growth but also to avoid a cost and time burn in terms of training a new hire to adapt to the company culture.

Let us look at some easy and effective measures that organizations can adopt to curb attrition among the star performers.

 

Avoid employee burn out

The first thing that companies must pay heed is to curb over-burdening employees with work. Stretching work hours on a regular basis not only plays with the employees’ work-life balance but also adversely affects one's mental and physical wellbeing. Employees too might take up additional tasks assigned by their managers to keep the achievement momentum on, often even more than one can handle, especially during challenging periods, the pandemic in this case.

According to the Achievers Workforce Institute Engagement and Retention Report for 2021, 51 per cent of employees currently working from home think that their supervisor doubts their productivity. This is bound to contribute to employee burnout since most of them - almost 44 percent – are prompted to log onto work earlier or stay online later. 

This gives a toss to the essential work-life balance that one intends to maintain leading the employee towards health issues. The same report mentions that a whopping 52 per cent of employees will job hunt in 2021 — up from 35 per cent in 2020. Among these 25 per cent are striving for a better work-life balance while 35 percent are looking for better compensation benefits.

 

Acknowledge achievements

To retain its workforce, organizations must ensure that employees are trusted upon,  acknowledged for every achievement and milestone that they reach. And the onus lies on the immediate superior the employee is dealing with. The report states that more than a third of employees feel that they are not recognized by their superiors; while a whopping 69 percent feel that their motivation and relationships within the organization would improve if their managers acknowledged their milestones.  

Thus, it is pertinent to take time out for effective employee engagement programs. While periodic reviews and assessments offer constructive feedback, it is crucial to offer apt solutions or suggestions to overcome those little hurdles that employees may face in their daily work. Over 66 per cent of employees would be more engaged at work if employers improved company culture, while almost 52 percent would be more engaged if their employer improved its diversity and inclusion. To put things in perspective, the power of a ‘thank you’ is often underestimated yet its effects in creating a culture of recognition, that not only reduces turnover but increases engagement and productivity at the same time, can never be undermined.

 

Design employee engagement programs 

It is rightly said that organizations are like families. The stronger the bonds are between the employees and employers, the more likely are the employees to stick to the organization. It is thus a necessity to prepare a well-knit employee communication network and employee engagement programs to ensure the employee feels connected to the company. This becomes even more important when situations like the current pandemic force employees to work out of their homes. 

The latest study shows that more and more employees today, are feeling less connected to their company or colleagues since the start of the pandemic. About 42 percent of the workforce believes that company culture has diminished since the onset of the pandemic, with most employees blaming lack of communication and effort to make remote employees feel connected.

 

Offer career development opportunities

Studies have revealed that organizations that offer career development options have a higher retention rate compared to those who don’t. It could be in the form of opening lateral and vertical movements within the company or sponsoring higher education, career development through training and seminars, participating in national as well as global events and competitions, etc. 

Many organizations have adopted voluntary skill development centers where employees can reskill and upskill themselves without having to take sabbaticals. Employees who are always craving more knowledge and skill development, take heed in addressing their needs.

 

Offer competitive compensations and benefits

According to the latest Achievers Workforce Institute survey, more than half the employees plan to look for a new job in 2021 - up from 43 per cent in 2019 and35 per cent in 2020 respectively. The reasons as mentioned above are competitive pay packages and better work-life balance. 

Good pay packages and additional perks and benefits like health, life, or disability insurances, academic sabbaticals, tuition fee reimbursement/sponsorship, paid holidays and vacations, ESOP options, etc. are crucial to attract and retain top talents.

With a great company culture and employee-friendly policies, organizations can not only ensure a cut in attrition but also head up in the race for the most preferred workplaces. Grow your business with your employees!

Our product Pathfinder helps organizations retain employees with its various tools and solutions. To see how, book a demo with us, etc.

data.title: Can a dedicated Employee Career Site increase Internal Fulfilment for an Enterprise?
data.content:
When the Coronavirus outbreak brought the global economic engine to a standstill, organisations were thrown into an abyss of financial turmoil.   

Enterprises were forced to resort to diverse techniques in order to protect monetary interests. Cost-cutting and tightening of institutional purse strings became a regular routine for companies, as cash-flow started to evolve into a pressing concern.  

Whilst most companies resorted to laying-off their workforce, industry experts pointed out that whilst being effective for startups and SMEs/SMBs, laying off large portions of the workforce is detrimental to a larger organisation’s health.  

Despite a lull in the economy, when the financial situation turns around eventually, these larger companies will find it difficult to secure the right talent to handle business demands.  

Hiring in large numbers when the economy bounces back can prove to be cumbersome and expensive, as the annual cost for external hiring has been steadily increasing over time. Today, a single hire can cost a company over 50,000 USD on average, taking into consideration other overheads such as on-boarding, training and development.  

To evade this potential problem, enterprises have initiated a wave of up-skilling and re-skilling programs for their employees. Internal job placement tool is helping organizations utilize their resources more efficiently, whilst simultaneously driving down costs associated with external hiring.  

However, efficient Workforce Optimisation remains a pipe-dream for a slew of companies all over the globe.  

Critically evaluating all of the available skills from within the organisation, and then, going about the process of filling the observable skill gaps has become increasingly tedious for enterprises. The lack of relevant and current employee data makes it difficult to gauge the overall skill-sets and experience of the employee. 

How can a dedicated Career Site help? 

A Career Site is a dedicated platform that is built for housing and analysing all of the employee’s personal employment related data. And, with an added layer of AI-powered capabilities, the platform can infer skill-gaps and recommend appropriate up-skilling courses.  

Career sites can be integrated into the existing historic ESS tool, which collects and collates employee related data constantly. All of this is done in real-time.  

Employees are notified at regular intervals to update the platform.

Most organisations relied on human effort, to scour through heaps of employee related data to successfully infer skill gaps and make suitable recommendations to the L&D department.  

This resulted in erroneous recommendations and unfilled skill-gaps amongst the employees in an organisation. 

However, the added layer of artificial intelligence in HR procedures helps isolate the required data, and filter out the rest.  

Finding the right talent from within saves companies millions, annually. And during a global pandemic, when hiring becomes more tedious and remote, efficient workforce optimisation could be the difference between life or death for an organisation.  

It is now becoming increasingly difficult for enterprises to locate the right resource for a job. Understanding skill-sets, experience, fitment and authenticity of talent becomes cumbersome for the remote-working model (WFH). 

Getedge helps you in finding the right talent from within the confines of the organization could result in millions being saved every year. And inevitably, help a business tide over the uncertain financial reckoning that was brought about by COVID-19.

data.title: How is Workforce Optimisation helping Enterprises save millions each year?
data.content:
The average expenditure for hiring and training a new employee can range anywhere between 6,000 – 18,000 USD a year. 

One of the most cost-effective practices in an enterprise today is workforce optimisation, because it allows organisations to find the right talent from within. 

Organisations around the globe spend millions each year to source, interview, recruit and train new hires. Yet, it was found to be financially more suitable to locate efficient workers from within. By up-skilling these internal resources, the need for external hiring dipped for large conglomerates, thereby flattening talent acquisition costs.  

Today, as the world grapples with the deadly Coronavirus outbreak, automation has arrived to pick up the pieces. Companies are automating every single redundant task, to speed up processes and produce results.  

HR Tech systems coupled with intelligent tools like AI are helping these enterprises identify future demands, and thus, successfully up-skill the employees to undertake newly evolving roles and job requirements.  

By studying all the skills and skill-sets that are present within the confines of a company, intelligent HR Tech systems can study the pain points associated with skill gaps and make the required recommendations.  

However, when addressing the idea of Workforce Optimisation, we need to understand that it goes beyond the rudimentary conversation surrounding Bench Optimisation and Employee re-skilling. The real conversation surrounds the primary notion: which is automation.  

Whilst costs are down with regard to Talent Acquisition and successful Internal Mobility practices, organisations all also saving millions by automating roles across the RMG (Resource Management Group) function.  

By utilising intelligent algorithms to scan, study and allocate employees to right jobs within, the need for larges RMGs with hundreds of executives ceases to be a reality. By reducing the number of excess resources in these RMGs, an organisation can save anywhere between 40,000 – 115,000 USD a year per employee.  

Another form of optimisation is the integration of HR Tech systems with existent ESS (Employee Self Service) tools. Most employees do not update information pertaining to skills and overall experience gained in real-time. This often makes it difficult for RMGs to accurately search and match resources to right job roles.  

By having a dedicated career portal and career path tools, employees are encouraged to regularly update their skills and experience, to have greater visibility into the internal talent pool. A career portal helps employees get their careers on track, which has been attributed to the reduction in overall attrition. It has been noted that companies with a dedicated Employee Career portal saw a decline of over 12% in overall attrition rates, with some enterprises reporting numbers as astounding as 40%.  

Automating the fulfillment pipeline serves as a double entendre: which is to not only reduce the number of resources required within an organization but also as a vessel to help manage talent. With stiff competition on the rise for talent, organizations need to invest more heavily into retaining skilled resources. data.title: The Need For Effective RMG's For Organizational Growth
data.content:
The sheer scale of the Coronavirus pandemic impacted organizations of all sizes, disrupting businesses across the globe. The infectious outbreak also forced international enterprises to change their priorities overnight.  

The sheer scale of the pandemic impacted organizations of all sizes, disrupting businesses across the globe. The infectious outbreak also forced international enterprises to change their priorities overnight.  The uncertainty in the economic environment sent departmental heads into a frenzy, as they tried to overcome the daunting task of cutting down non-essential costs across functions like Marketing, Operations, Internal IT, Delivery and HR.   

A direct impact of this economic speedbump is still visible within the staffing strategy for global enterprises. Today, in a bid to reduce Talent Acquisition costs, organisations are choosing to up-skill / re-skill their existing employees as opposed to hiring externally. 

In order to bring about this change, Resource management Groups (RMGs) need to have a clear and concise overview of the:  

  • Available skills possessed by the current workforce   
  • Billing / Revenue impact of skills by an employee 
  • Opportunities available to relocate employees for revenue optimization 

 The Current Challenge Across organizations: 

Most organizations do not have a structured skill repository. On the rare occasion where do they do have one in place, it is often not up-to-date and is managed loosely on Excel sheets. And in an attempt to shed some light on the aforementioned point, it is important to know that ‘Skills’ management on an Excel sheet is not the most efficient way to collaborate across functions and service lines. 

How Does RMG Become A Saviour? 

RMGs are at a strategic vantage point, with constant access to critical insights like:  

a.     Skill available within the workforce  

b.     Skills required to fulfil existing demand 

c.     Skills required for upcoming/incoming demands;  

If Resource Management Groups are provided with all the necessary information and insights pertaining to the skills of a candidate and their career aspirations, the RMGs can work alongside L&D and Human Resource teams to ensure the investments in training and certifications are in line with organizational demands. By doing so, they can provide the company with inputs about: 

  1. Strategic skill investment areas 
  2. Channelize the skills required for defining demands in the direction of the organisation`s interest 
  3. Opportunities to re-allocate employees for better billing rates or revenue 

Placing the right skill, at the right time, at the right cost / best return. 

How Can Organizations Benefit From This? 

  • Reduced ‘Mark to external’ saves additional costs associated with external hiring 
  • Optimized re-skilling improves employee satisfaction and reduces employee turnover, which eventually improves revenue per employee.  
  • Enhanced Customer Experience (CX) – leading to multiple other benefits 
  • Help L&D teams to improve the ROI on training and certifications  
  • Improve the overall relevance of training to match an employee’s desirability 
  • Better profit margins and Revenue – Employee ratio 

After all, every penny saved is a penny earned. 

Why Is It Pertinent To Have An Updated Skills Management System Now? 

The rapid pace at which technological investments have changed across industries over the years, the rate at which people are equipping themselves with various skills and the sudden change in the global financial landscape has made it important for the organization to keep a track of its skill repository in real-time. The fact is that professionals are now gearing up for the 'future of work', learning new skills. At the same time, organizations are increasingly becoming 'people centric' and implementing varied technologies and systems to help their people grow to the next level. 

 This is exactly the gap EDGE Pathfinder fills. It is very integrated into the talent supply chain; has capabilities of forecasting, planning, internal mobility and charting an employees' career path. Its smart features help organizations analyze the existing skill gap within the organization. 

EDGE Pathfinder learns from the Smart AI EDGE GraphTM, which has analyzed over 10 million job descriptions and 35 million candidate profiles. It helps organizations match the goals and aspirations of their workforce, aligning them to business targets and drive impact. It recreates their career grail by recommending apt career paths, provides upskilling opportunities, and helps employees achieve career aspirations connecting their success to the organization's success, igniting their passion for finding their true calling.

Thus, putting the employee in the centre of all talent decisions makes the employee feel valued, engaged, and future proof in your organization, thereby making the organization more efficient and future proof. At EDGE, this is how we use tech for good — Book a Demo

data.title: How can an Enterprise increase its overall revenue by deploying an AI-powered Talent Acquisition platform?
data.content:
Surveys and reports have shown that over 28% of future job openings will go unfulfilled, resulting in a loss of billable work hours. This in turn reduces an organisation’s top-line, which inevitably hurts stakeholders across the enterprise.  

With the onset of digitization, automation and intelligent systems, analysts predicted a global shift in the hiring order. Jobs and skillsets that were relevant today, would slowly start to become irrelevant by the dawn of the next decade.  

And this calculated assumption has held its ground. Over the last 5 years, various IT and Tech related job profiles have either become obsolete or redundant. And inevitably, a regular job profile has evolved into an entity that requires new skills and experiences.  

In light of this cataclysmic shift, organisations are finding it increasingly difficult to source the right talent. The hiring methodology that relied on ‘Human Instincts’ is gravely flawed and has resulted in over 40% of organisations declaring that they lack ‘Qualified Talent’. 

So, what went wrong? Why has the entire Talent Acquisition pipeline for an enterprise turned sour? 

The answer is simple: inadequate disruption across the hiring channel.  

With the arrival of intelligent platforms powered by Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML), the ability to process data and infer insights became a regular norm for enterprises all over. By applying the same concept to the hiring process, companies have seen a noticeable improvement.  

Over 22% of organisations utilising AI-ML for talent related decisions have fared better than others in the departments of hiring, retention and diversity. How?  

Finding the right talent: Bad hires v/s Bottom-line 

No longer a novelty in the space of hiring, AI has made its entry into the field by displaying immediate results. With the help of ‘Contextual Analysis’ and ‘Data Analytics’, AI platforms were able to identify prospective employees by inferring their overall qualification, experience and skill-sets possessed.  

By doing so effectively, the platform is able to source the right talent for diverse profiles, departments and verticals with lesser time. Furthermore, by assessing overall fitment, the right candidate is sourced accurately. Companies spend over 10,000 USD annually to train a single employee. Hence, bad hires affect the bottom-line.  

Internal Fulfilment for Cost Effectiveness 

In the wake of the COVID-19 outbreak, organisations all over the world are now looking to fulfil arising job openings by sourcing the right talent internally.  

Workforce Optimization has gone beyond resource utilization, and will now become a matter of corporate profits. In order to reduce hiring and training costs, organisations are deploying AI-powered platforms to optimise their bench.  

Benched candidates, that are suitable for other openings across the enterprise, can be allocated immediately. Furthermore, with the help of Intelligent Learning Recommendations, these benched executives can be up-skilled appropriately to undertake new profiles and job roles.  

Removing the Human Bias 

Researchers have stated that the Human Bias has been repeatedly responsible for bad hires. Hiring Managers that rely on their gut instincts, do so without quantifying the logic behind undertaking a hiring decision. Often, the best employee is ignored in favour of a flamboyant smooth-talker, which could yield poor results for a company. It has been observed that, that an average IT/ITeS enterprise spends over 250,000 USD for training new hires.  

AI-powered talent decision platforms have the ability to scan through a resume, gauge skill-sets and appropriately stack-rank them according to fitment.  

Through this process, a hiring manager can see the most ideal candidates based on their overall score. Also, by setting certain constraints/filters, the most ideal fit for a company can be sourced quickly.  

The positive attributes behind an AI-powered Talent Acquisition platform are far beyond what you’ve just read. The platform taxonomizes the skill-sets, breaks down hiring bottlenecks, reduces the hiring cycle-time etc.  

Hence, at a time when saving money is of utmost importance for an organisation, spending millions on bad hires shouldn’t be in existence.

data.title: What does the 'Future of Work' mean for an Enterprise, post the COVID-19 pandemic?
data.content:
The Coronavirus pandemic (COVID-19) brought businesses and operations to a grinding halt all across the globe. Enterprises rolled back on hiring, and SMEs/SMBs shut workplaces till further notice.  

Since it was first declared a global calamity by the World Health Organisation (WHO) in late February 2019, a market survey report has showed that over 65% of companies shut down, pending an economic revival. Also, more than 60% of all the organisations in the world either froze their hiring channels or deferred joining dates for the future.  Even though only about 4 – 7% of companies have laid off a portion of their workforce, the United States has announced that over 22 million individuals filed for unemployment benefits since the beginning of the pandemic.  Though things are looking better the road to recovery is still foggy.

The WorldWorld has changed forever. The last time the economy took such a brutal beating was in 2008. However, analysts predict that the economic backlash caused by COVID-19 will be far more significant. For the first time in history, the value of a single barrel of crude oil dipped below the USD 1 mark.  

Yet, as the saying goes, ‘This too shall pass. Just like how the crude oil market self-corrected its value overnight, so will the global economy. Once the potency of the virus declines and vaccines begin to hit the market, organisations and enterprises will need to swing back into action.  

But we must remember that with such a trenching impact on the economy, jobs and working conditions will never be the same again. Skills will evolve, redundant roles will get axed, and the automation of repetitive tasks will forge the way forward.  

This doesn’t translate into a loss of jobs but more of an evolution. So, how will organisations cope with the gradual shift in working conditions and requirements so as to efficiently hire for the Future of Work?  

Planning and Forecasting 

Enterprises will need to start arriving at the idea of Talent Decisioning with a more holistic approach.  

HR leaders will need to be more aware of the market and understand how businesses, projects and goals have changed. By understanding how a client’s business requirements have changed, the talent pipeline will also have to be modified to source the right individual for a job.  

Evaluating skills required, skills present within the organisation, project requirements, client goals etc., will become much more critical whilst seeking new talent.  

Career Sites 

An important yet often ignored facet of HR Technology is the requirement for robust career sites.  A dedicated career site helps an organisation by tackling two defenders at the same time! 

The platform serves as an internal repository of information pertaining to the workforce’s skills, experience and overall performance metrics. A robust career site ensures employees regularly update the platform with the necessary skills. And with an added layer of intelligence, the platform can deduce skill gaps and make relevant up-skilling/re-skilling to ensure employees start imbibing skills for the incoming requirements.  

The second facet of the Career Site is that it helps in Workforce Optimization. Hiring managers can access relevant profiles with just a few clicks, thereby fulfilling open positions internally. It reduces the overall cost to hire (C2H) and helps in employee career progression.  

It is essential to know that adequate career progression reduces overall employee attrition.  

Enhance Recruitment with Technology 

Technology in the field of recruitment has existed for years, but it has to go beyond the rudimentary ATS (Application Tracking System).  

Sifting through hundreds of resumes, shortlisting and marking them to the Talent Acquisition team has always been tedious, resulting in hours of workforce wasted.  

HR Technology was born when HR applications began adding a layer of intelligence with the help of AI and Machine Learning (ML). Now, with AI, the tool or application can scan through dozens of resumes in a second and stack rank them according to relevance. This reduces the time invested, thereby reducing the overall hiring cycle duration.  

The Talent Acquisition pipeline is becoming increasingly intelligent with the help of technology. Organisations that adapt quickly and utilise technology will solve future talent-related shortages, which in turn will positively impact their business.
